column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82287,2018,Management Foundations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. HW Volberda'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Several major classical contributions will be discussed such as those of Taylor (1911), Fayol (1916), Barnard (1938), Simon (1947), Selznick (1957), Penrose (1959), Burns & Stalker (1966), Thompson (1967), Mintzberg (1973), and Chandler (1977). These contributions will be assessed by using three idealized management perspectives: classical, modern and post-modern (Volberda 1998). Attention will be paid to the development and evolution of these perspectives. In addition, recent topics in research in management like managerial cognition and knowledge integration; managerial intentionality, strategy formation and co-evolution, and managerial theories of the firm are discussed. The discussion will focus on how various management perspectives may contribute to the investigation of these topics. Students are expected to present assignments about the topics discussed.

Participants will write a conceptual paper exploring how the management perspectives discussed, including the associated classical contributions are related to the intended PhD topic, and the implications for the nature of research questions, and research methodologies to be used. The paper will be written as a “Research Note” using the style guide and authors instruction of the Academy of Management Review.
The students will receive reviews of their paper from their colleagues.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This course has two aims. First to provide an overview of the scientific foundations of the management discipline by discussing examples of classical contributions. Second, to relate the insights acquired to the intended research area of the student by writing a scholarly paper.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80672,2018,Management accounting,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'dr. F Elsinger']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In het vakgebied Management Accounting staat de rol van de controller als lid van het management team centraal. In het kort komt die rol neer op het bewaken van de bedrijfseconomische vitaliteit van de organisatie. Dit betekent dat de controller als financieel manager in staat moet zijn om een vertaling te geven van wensen, plannen en voornemens enerzijds en uitkomsten, resultaten en prestaties anderzijds naar de financiële dimensie waarin de doelen van de organisatie zijn uitgedrukt.
Tijdens het vak komen de volgende onderwerpen aan de orde:

column2: • Kostenbepaling;
• Kostenallocatie.
• Kostenfuncties;
• Middellange termijnplanning.
• Budgettering;
• Verschillenanalyse;
• Transfer pricing en prestatiemeting;

column1: Tijdens de hoorcolleges zullen de leerdoelen voornamelijk conceptueel benaderd worden, waarbij de basisliteratuur bekend wordt verondersteld. Het gaat om de ‘rode draad’, waarbij accenten meer concreet zullen worden geïllustreerd.

Tijdens de responsiecolleges staat de vaardigheid centraal. Het probleemoplossend vermogen zal hier gestimuleerd worden aan de hand van het uitwerken van vooraf opgegeven vraagstukken, waarvan de moeilijkheidsgraad op ‘tentamenniveau’ ligt.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De verschillende typen kosten in organisaties classificeren door onderscheid te maken tussen categorieën als productkosten en periodekosten, en directe en indirecte kosten;
• Diverse kostenconcepten identificeren, zoals opportuniteitskosten, out-of-pocket kosten, gezonken kosten, incrementele kosten, marginale kosten en gemiddelde kosten;
• Alternatieve kostenschattingsmethoden toepassen en het gedrag van verschillende kostenfuncties interpreteren;
• Kostenallocatietechnieken zoals activity-based costing toepassen;
• Cost-volume-profit analyses uitvoeren;
• Statische en flexibele budgetten onderscheiden, en variantie-analyses uitvoeren voor materiaal- en arbeidskosten voor organisaties die standaard kostenmethoden gebruiken;
• Implicaties voor organisaties van alternatieve modellen van responsibility accounting and transfer pricing bepalen;
• Accounting informatie selecteren die bruikbaar is om interne plannings-, prijsbepalings- en beheersingsbesluiten te nemen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82921,2018,Management and Leadership in Media Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The growing mediatization of organizations and society, increasing complexity of organizational issues, and accelerating competition produce fundamental changes in the media industry and around our understanding of the importance of media. Therefore, we need scientifically reflective and practically relevant approaches for managing and leading processes and practices of change in regards to media. Towards this aim, the course provides an overview of topics such as organization, management and leadership and works towards a reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. In particular, it will address concepts and approaches for reflectively engaging in everyday organizational phenomena such as teams, groups, sensemaking, culture, power and politics, knowledge and learning, strategy, as well as creativity and change.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication. Students will learn to use theories and methods sensible and reflect on them. This forms the basis for grounded, conscientious, and successful actions in practice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current concepts, approaches and theories of management and leadership that are relevant for working in media organizations;
• How media organizations and practitioners manage processes and practices around individuals, groups, and organization-wide phenomena.
• Identify the need for and function of management and leadership in their context;
• Apply management and leadership approaches and theories reflectively;
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80900,2018,Management challenges in international organisations,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Shemla'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of women, minorities, and disabled people have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic issue in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever growing.

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on gaining awareness for the role of culture in organizations and on developing skills to manage diversity.

Each session is a module addressing a particular leadership challenge facing executives in the global arena (e.g., leading a diverse team, managing change, etc.). The teaching approach will vary, with a mix of lecture input, group discussion, case analysis, experiential exercises, and guest lectures.
The students will have the opportunity to learn from the experiences and insights of the following guest lecturers:
A. Mr. Jacques Kemp, Former CEO of ING Asia/Pacific, will talk about strategic issues in leading international organizations
B. Mrs. Josefine van Zanten, Senior Vice President Culture Change at Royal DSM
The course grade will be computed as a weighted average of five elements
e. Cultural immersion experience/Service learning project 30%
f. Optional task - Personal inquiry (Bonus of up to 0.5 points)
Assignments c, d, and g will be completed in teams. All other assignments are individual tasks.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this topic participants should:
- Acquire knowledge on managing people and teams in global contexts
- Experience first-hand accounts of the challenges facing leading diverse others
- Gain awareness of their own culture and how it influences the way they see the world
- Raise greater intercultural sensitive and empathy
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80181,2018,Management of Diversity and Inclusion,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['J Wu, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Organizations around the world are becoming increasingly diverse in their membership. As a result, cultural diversity, expertise diversity, and a growing number of other forms of diversity are higher on the management agenda than ever before. Diversity offers a complex challenge. On the one hand, diversity may be a source of inspiration for creativity, innovation, and high-quality decision making, leading to high performance and a competitive advantage for organizations. On the other hand, diversity may be associated with hurdles to organizational careers for members of underrepresented groups, and diverse teams may face communication problems and interpersonal tensions that stand in the way of high-quality team performance. The challenge for the management of diversity thus is to create a context in which the benefits of diversity can be realized while attenuating its potentially more problematic aspects.

This course builds on bachelor and master teaching in Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management to give a representative coverage of theories of diversity, and to explore their applications in diversity management, for instance as it is expressed in best practices. It aims to develop a deeper insight in the processes underlying the positive and negative effects associated with diversity – insights that can be used to recognize, understand, and address diversity challenges in practice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have insight into main theories of diversity
• Be able to apply these theories to recognize and address diversity-related management challenges

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81299,2018,Management of Media and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. HJCJ Hitters'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This seminar focuses on organizational aspects of the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of firms. The central question is to what extent firms in the media and cultural industries are different from other firms with respect to initiating, managing and controlling business processes. This question will be analyzed from three angles. We will first systematically and critically assess the nature and structure of creative media markets, in which symbolic or experience value plays an important role and companies have to operate in a dynamic field of continuous technological, social and cultural transformations. Secondly, whereas most management literature centers on strategies of large cross-media corporations, in this seminar we aim at understanding the conduct and business ventures of small-scale enterprises and entrepreneurs (SMSE’s). These are mostly positioned at the beginning of the creative value chain: the phase of concept and idea creation and the first stages of production. After all, at this stage successful management of creativity is crucial to innovation. The third angle examines the relationship between incumbents and new enterprises in the media and creative industries. Here we will focus on issues such as innovation failure, routines, leadership and transformation. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The specific character of organization and management in the media and creative industries.
• Current theories, approaches and debates in this field.
• Systematically analyze and critically reflect on fundamental and practical challenges in managing and organizing contemporary media and creative industries firms.
• Analyze independently an empirical case study.
• Find alternatives and solutions for challenges that media and creative companies are facing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80817,2018,Management science,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Fragkos'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Important decisions cannot be left to intuition alone. We need to communicate the structure of our reasoning, defend it to adversarial challenge and make presentations that show we have done a thorough analysis. We also need to make sense out of various sources of data, organize the inputs of experts and colleagues, and use state-of-the-art business software to provide analytical support to our reasoning. To equip you to be more effective in these tasks is the overall objective of this course. The emphasis is not on the quantitative aspects, but on the qualitative insights that come from using models to aid managerial thinking and decision making.

The course is multi-disciplinary in nature and links to a number of other areas, including finance, operations management, marketing and accounting, through the choice of cases, thus adding an analytical dimension to the teaching of these areas.

column2: <li>
Improving awareness and enhancing your intuition on decision making
<li>
Focusing on relevant information
<li>
Modeling complex decisions
<li>
Making decisions in the face of uncertainty
<li>
Understanding human behavior and risk attitudes in business
<li>
The process of Decision Making
<li>
Scenario, Sensitivity and Risk Analysis
<li>
Business Simulation
<li>
Structure and Analysis of Decisions
<li>
Spreadsheet-based software tools for Decision Making

column1: Participants should be familiar with basic mathematical concepts and the basics of spreadsheet modeling in Excel. For those who are not familiar with this, we suggest to go through chapter 2 “Introduction to Spreadsheet Modeling” of the book. Further resources will be given before the start of the course, and an excel workshop will be organized. We expect that the participants prepare their classes and actively participate in the case study discussions.
This course is worth 3 ECTS (1 foundation ECTS and 2 master ECTS).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>By the end of this course you will be equipped with specific skills in the areas of data analysis, structuring decisions, building decision models, risk assessment, and decision making under uncertainty, recognising areas where business analysis can add value, selecting appropriate types of analyses and applying them in a small-scale, quick-turnaround fashion.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80119,2018,Management van maatschappelijke risico's,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. F Koster', 'prof.dr. HJM Fenger', 'prof.dr. RJ van der Veen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus behandelt de sociologische analyse van instituties en hun uitkomsten. Om precies te zijn wordt dit theoretische raamwerk gebruikt voor het analyseren van arbeidsmarktinstituties en hoe deze de verdeling en de kwaliteit van arbeid beïnvloeden. We gaan daarbij in op vraagstukken rondom werkloosheid, arbeidsmarktsegmentatie, flexibilisering van arbeidsrelaties en werkonzekerheid. Dat betekent dat wij ons richten op individualisering van de arbeidsrelatie en globalisering van arbeidsmarkten en de sociale gevolgen van deze ontwikkelingen.

Terwijl de overheid de arbeidsmarkt reguleert via loonbeleid (zoals het geval is bij minimumlonen), ontslagrecht, socialezekerheidsbeleid, enzovoorts, beïnvloeden werkgeversverenigingen en vakbonden de arbeidsmarkt door onderhandelingsprocessen rondom arbeidsomstandigheden, lonen en beroepsopleidingen, die resulteren in collectieve overeenkomsten. De instituties beschermen werknemers tegen risico’s zoals werkloosheid, ziekte en arbeidsongeschiktheid, armoede en pensioen. Ontwikkelingen als individualisering en globalisering kunnen van invloed zijn op de risico’s en de mate van bescherming die de instituties bieden. Vandaar dat vraagstukken rond arbeidsmarktregulering en sociale risico’s vanuit een dynamisch perspectief worden benaderd – meer specifiek wordt aandacht besteed aan economische, sociale en institutionele ontwikkelingen en hun gevolgen voor de arbeidsmarkt.  De vraag hoe nationale overheden en de verschillende arbeidsmarktpartijen omgaan met die veranderen komt ook aan de orde.

Er wordt in het bijzonder aandacht besteed aan hoe de institutionalisering van de arbeidsmarkt kan verschillen (zoals bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het gegeven dat de mate waarin en wijze waarop arbeidsmarkten worden gecoördineerd verschilt tussen landen). Belangrijke vragen zijn hoe de verschillen in arrangementen leiden tot verschillen in arbeidsmarktbeleid en hoe dit vervolgens het functioneren en de gevolgen van arbeidsmarkten beïnvloedt.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het succesvol afronden van dit vak kunnen studenten:

column2: • Aangeven hoe verzorgingsstaatinstituties en arbeidsmarktinstituties de verdeling en kwaliteit van arbeid vormgeven;
• Reflecteren op de relatie tussen verzorgingsstaatinstituties en economische, sociale en politieke uitkomsten;
• Sociologische theorieën over verzorgingsstaten en arbeidsmarktcoördinatie identificeren;
• Het sociologische raamwerk toepassen teneinde sociaal beleid op het gebied van arbeidsmarkten en de uitkomsten daarvan te analyseren;
• Onderzoeksmateriaal kritisch beoordelen;
• Op een heldere en effectieve wijze schriftelijk verslag doen van resultaten.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80684,2018,Management van technologie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. PL van den Berg', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Technologie is al eeuwenlang één van de belangrijkste pijlers van de economie. Zowel in de productiegerichte sectoren als in dienstverlenende bedrijven speelt technologie een belangrijke rol. Zonder technologische vooruitgang verliezen bedrijven concurrentiekracht. Managers staan voor de vraag of de huidige technologie in hun producten en productieprocessen nog wel up-to-date is, en wat de ontwikkelingen zijn van alternatieve technologieën. Moet de organisatie doorgaan met de huidige technologie of moet zij overstappen op een opkomende alternatieve technologie? Wat kunnen de consequenties zijn van deze keuze? In het kort, hoe kunnen managers relevante technologieën herkennen en op het juiste moment op de juiste wijze inpassen binnen het bedrijf?

Voor het vak Management van technologie gaan studenten een technologie strategie ontwikkelen voor een bedrijf dat hightech producten verkoopt. De studenten zullen de technologische voor- en nadelen van de huidige technologie in de producten analyseren, als ook van twee alternatieve technologieën die in deze producten kunnen worden toegepast. Om een keuze te maken uit deze technologieën moet de student ook het bedrijf en de omgeving analyseren. De studenten zullen verkennen wat de gevolgen zijn van deze keuze op de verschillende bedrijfsfuncties, denkend aan R&D, HRM, operations, supply chain, marketing etc.

Dit vak beschrijft hoe technologie benut kan worden in bedrijven. Hierbij gaat het niet om hoe op korte termijn aan een marktvraag kan worden voldaan door middel van technologie (“market pull”), maar hoe voor de lange termijn ontwikkelingen in de technologie kunnen worden benut (“technology push”). Voor aanvang van het vak selecteert elk studententeam een bedrijf uit een lijst hightech bedrijven. Elk bedrijf gebruikt een specifieke technologie in zijn hightech producten. Door middel van zelfstudie, verplichte bijeenkomsten en vrijwillige bijeenkomsten zullen studententeams het bedrijf en de huidige technologie analyseren (Opdracht 1), de alternatieve technologieën analyseren en de impact van het implementeren van deze technologieën op het bedrijf en de bedrijfsomgeving (Opdracht 2) en deze bevindingen integreren in een advies voor een technologie strategie (Opdracht 3). Dit advies zal schriftelijk gepresenteerd worden aan het bedrijf. De studententeams bestaan uit 6 RSM studenten. De teams worden begeleid door twee coaches; een ouderejaars RSM student en een Master student van de Technische Universiteit Delft. Let op! Er is geen schriftelijke toets voor dit vak, maar er zijn wel 4 bijeenkomsten welke verplicht zijn (inclusief bijeenkomsten waarin de kennis van de student wordt getest).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • Samenwerken op een technologisch onderwerp;
• Een technologie gedreven aanpak gebruiken als een alternatieve manier om concurrerende producten/diensten en productieprocessen te ontwikkelen;
• Systematisch de impact van technologie op bedrijf en bedrijfsomgeving beoordelen;
• Een strategisch advies uitbrengen aan een bedrijf.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80184,2018,Managerial and group decision making,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Isaakyan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

One of the most important actions performed by people in organizations is making decisions. Decision making takes place at many different levels of the organization and can have enormous implications for organizational functioning and performance. This course provides an in-depth view of several theoretical perspectives on decision making, at an individual level as well as at a group-level. In many business situations, it is not possible to solve a decision making problem by rationally analyzing all options. Therefore, an initial part of the course is devoted to understanding the nature, causes, and implications of human decision making limitations. Second, because decision making often takes place in a social context, a part of the course is devoted to social decision making and deals with how individuals coordinate their decisions in a social environment and how social influences affect decision making by individuals. Furthermore, decisions are often delegated to groups, because groups are supposed to possess more relevant resources like knowledge and perspectives. In reality, however, it is often the case that joint decision making is suboptimal. We will discuss the reasons why groups often do not use their potential, and how this could be improved. Finally, in many situations two or more parties that have different preferences need to make a joint decision. In the last part of the course, we will therefore discuss negotiation.

To meet course objectives, the course uses articles published in international journals, book chapters, lectures, and class discussions. Reading assignments provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class (some classes will have additional material after class). Lectures will supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course, students should:

column2: <li>
Have insight into main theories of individual, social, and group decision making;
<li>
Be able to apply these decision making theories to challenges facing current-day organizations;
<li>
Be able to solve decision making problems by translating academic knowledge and thinking into a theoretically and empirically anchored model and deriving recommendations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80813,2018,Managerial decision making & negotiation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Paolacci'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

What are the biases that affect the choices of managers and consumers, and what heuristics do these agents use? How do other people influence their decisions? How can you approach decisions so to optimize their outcomes? How can you create value in a negotiation? How do you and succeed in obtaining a bigger share of the pie? We will try to answer these questions by using a mixture of lectures, class discussions and exercises, and assignments.
This course is worth 3 ECTS (1 foundation ECT and 2 master ECTS).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
(1) to give you a better understanding of how people make decisions
(2) to make you a better decision maker and negotiator
At the end of the course, the student:
(1) Will know what heuristics and biases are naturally entrenched in human judgments
(2) Will master the most common persuasion techniques
(3) Will know how to make and promote better decisions as judged by decision makers
(4) Will know how to approach a negotiation
(5) Will have experienced value creation and claim during negotiations</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80235,2018,Managing Innovation Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof. SM Ansari - Loan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not professionally managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate and thus create new value, and among those who are able to create new value, few are able to capture it. In this course, we will learn why firms struggle to create and capture new value. Finally, we will share a number of concepts on how to implement innovation in an organization. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation better.
For further information and inspiration, please read the articles below:

column2: • Harvard Business Review (2002). “Inspiring Innovation.” Harvard Business Review, 80(8): pp. 39-49
• Dyer, J. et al (2009). “The Innovator’s DNA.” Harvard Business Review, 87(12): pp. 60-67

column1: Attendance is mandatory (as there is no exam) and your participation matters. The format is intense, but allows you to focus on the subject matter and to have engaging debates in the classroom. Applying the theoretical knowledge to real-life situations is a central aspect of this course. Therefore, it will include several practical examples.

All sessions will be highly interactive, with sufficient room for discussion, student presentations focusing on applying the theory to practical examples, and small group exercises. The approach is strongly participative. The instructor will introduce ideas, concepts and methodologies and discuss these in relation to your experiences and views. There will be a number of sessions where you are asked to experiment with the ideas and concepts that we introduce, so that you understand better how they work and how you may be able to apply them in the future. Hence, in the spirit of fruitful in-class discussion, students are expected to come prepared to class by having read the mandatory readings. In each session, there will be plenty of practitioner examples from different kinds of organizations to illustrate the perils and excitement of innovation and strategy. You are asked to think and debate critically.

In several sessions we will use case studies. In order to have an interesting session based on case studies, you obviously need to prepare these thoroughly. A good case preparation often requires three readings: one to get the overall story, one to do a thorough analysis of the problem, and one to formulate solutions.
Teamwork and leveraging complementarities – as in real life – are essential capabilities you should take away from RSM. You will be asked to form teams of 4-5 students.

Shaz Ansari is a Professor of Strategy at Judge Business School, University of Cambridge and Faculty at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. He holds a PhD from University of Cambridge. He serves on the Editorial Boards of Academy of Management Journal, Academy of Management Review, Organization Science, Journal of Management Studies and Organization Studies, and is member of CCGN – a confederation of University of Cambridge faculties, research centres and academics interested in corporate governance.  He is also a star member of Erasmus Research Institute of Management (ERIM). His research and teaching interests include institutional processes, logics and diffusion of practices; framing, social movements, technological and management innovations; ecosystem strategies, reputation management, and bottom-of-the-pyramid strategies, corporate governance and social, environmental and ethical issues in management including climate change. He has published in several leading academic journals including Academy of Management Journal, Academy of Management Review, Strategic Management Journal, Organization Science, Journal of Management Studies, Research Policy, Industrial and Corporate Change, Strategic Organization, and Organization Studies.

Professor Ansari's expertise in executive education includes strategic management, corporate governance, social innovation, and corporate social responsibility, technological and business model innovation. He has contributed to executive education programs in many organizations, including McKinsey, Airbus. Shell, British Telecom, China Development Bank, Nokia, Laing O'Rourke, UNICEF, Essex County Council, KLEC (Kuala Lumpur Education City).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To understand the importance of innovation: Why is it relevant? What does innovation deliver?
<li>
To conceptualize what the different types of innovation are and how they need to be tackled differently.
<li>
To develop understanding of managing innovation internally and externally: How to manage projects or harness the power of users in the innovation process?
<li>
To get familiarized with disruptive innovations: What to do about them? How to disrupt an industry?
<li>
To help you think about the ways in which we can enhance the likelihood of innovation’s success in the market.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79611,2018,Managing Interactive Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. IF van Meerkerk'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive governance is therefore a central concept in this course. Different perspectives on interactive governance are discussed, which also have consequences for how management in interactive governance is framed and which strategies are accentuated. Interactive governance pays attention to both participation and self-organization. The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects; the latter indicates that citizens themselves show self-organizing capacity for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: energy, health, water and urban development.

Regarding interactive governance, special attention will be devoted to leadership styles and different management strategies, like project and process management and boundary spanning activities that can be used in different situations and contexts. Interactive forms of governance are not self-executive due to various and oftentimes conflicting values, perceptions and interests. Connective and boundary spanning management is needed to stimulate and facilitate interaction between actors in interactive governance networks. In this course the concept of connective network management is discussed and explained. The main question this course addresses is: how is (network) management able to deal with the complexity (boundary-crossing nature of issues, dynamics, conflict of interests between actors, etc.) in interactive forms of governance and which (combinations of) strategies lead to good outcomes (innovation, effectiveness, legitimacy, and trust)?

The behavior, attitudes and skills of managers are discussed. What kind of activities do they exactly deploy, why and with which results? In complex networks of different (public, private, societal) actors an important feature of management is the establishment of relational capacity in order to connect different interests, values and viewpoints.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completion of the course students are able to:

column2: • To analyze the complex nature of interactive governance networks and processes (in terms of dynamics and interrelatedness);
• To distinguish and apply different perspectives on interactive governance;
• To understand the differences between government-induced (participation) and society induced (self-organization) interactive governance approaches and processes;
• To formulate critical conditions for effective, efficient and legitimate management of complex interactive governance processes;
• To determine management strategies fitting specific case study circumstances and situations (contingency approach);
• To formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with complex interactive governance processes and projects.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80178,2018,Managing NGO's,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In this master elective, the management of NPOs and NGOs will be discussed:

column2: <li>
How do they formulate their mission?
<li>
How do they attract and manage the necessary resources (donations, volunteers)?
<li>
How do they select projects and programs they will fund or manage?
<li>
In what way is their governance structured?
<li>
How do they relate to the other spheres: businesses and governments?

column1: During the assignments you will be actively connecting research and practice conducting pragmatic real life issues of NPOs. Although the cases are presented as fictive, experiences of previous years show that we are able to share your reports with many NPOs/NGOs in our network. Next to the lectures given by Prof. dr. Lucas Meijs (Professor of Strategic Philanthropy) and Stephanie Maas, a number of guest lectures from scholars as well as practitioners are part of the elective.

During your academic studies at RSM, the focus has probably been on the business sphere, and potentially on the interaction of this sphere with the governmental sphere. You have studied management techniques and theories and you know everything about the strategy, marketing, financial management and HRM of these organizations. However, the sphere of civil society, is probably a field you do not know much about. A field that is equally important, since you, as a future manager, will have to deal with a complex stakeholder context, in which the third sphere becomes increasingly present. As a business manager, you will find that Corporate Social Responsibility becomes more and more important and that you will have to keep in mind societal issues as well as developments in the business world.

Or perhaps, you would like to become part of this civil society, by working for an NGO or NPO. That is, if you are not already part of it. Many students like yourself, volunteer for a student organization or for a sports club. Are you a volunteer or have you been a volunteer in the past?

Next to the fact that it is recommended to learn more about the civil society sector in terms of your professional and personal development, philanthropic management might also interest you because these organizations are increasingly involved with ‘business-like behavior’. Non-profit, nongovernmental and philanthropic organizations today face many challenges that are similar to those within the corporate sector; challenges that are relatively new to the philanthropic sector. Just like businesses, these organizations face external pressure to operate more effectively and efficiently. While trying to deal with this challenge, the organization will however also have to keep the social goals of the organization in mind.
What is expected from you (methods of assessment)?
In order for you to develop a solid background in the theoretical and practical aspects of philanthropic management, we require the following from you:

column2: <li>
Presence and active participation during all the lectures and guest lectures;
<li>
Preparation of the lectures by reading the obligated literature;
<li>
The completion of two assignments (which will form the final grade):
<ul>

column3: An individual theoretical assignment (40%; to be found on blackboard);
A more practical orientated assignment in groups (60% consisting of a written report (45%) and group presentation (15%)).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the moment, Western governments are making severe budget cuts in order to repair the damage caused by the financial crisis, handing over more responsibilities to its citizens. Meanwhile, businesses are reorganizing, which often means that they are slimming down, with many employees declared redundant. In the Arab world, citizens are calling upon their government to take its responsibilities. In North-Korea every step of the average citizen is still monitored. And the BRIC countries are experiencing economic growth like never before.

Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope.  In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time. New parties have started to play an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

What is often forgotten as an important actor in society is the civil society sphere in which philanthropic nongovernmental and non-profit organizations are active. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as the need for distributing medical care for those who have little access to it, to reduce poverty, reduce emissions, save the whales or advocate for human rights. Many of them are focused upon advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, the context in which these NPOs and NGOs operate is very diverse (maybe even more diverse!). Just like for-profit organizations, many different types of NPO’s and NGO’s exist. Just like for-profit organizations, these organizations serve a mission and have their particular strategies. As such, just like for-profit organizations, these organizations need to be managed properly in order to achieve their goals. In this course, you will see however, that the way in which these organizations are managed, is completely different than in the for-profit or governmental sector.

The managing, governing and consulting of for example grant-making organizations, fundraisers, hospitals, museums, sport associations, action and pressure groups is nowadays considered to be a specialization within the field of management. The skills and knowledge that are needed in this field differ from the skills required in business settings. In this elective, Managing NGO’s, the aim is to provide you with an insight into this specialization and to help you build the skills and knowledge needed to understand this important sector.

During the elective, you will be provided with a theoretical and practical background of the management of philanthropic, nonprofit and nongovernmental organizations. A number of guest lectures have been organized, during which organizations provide an insight into the management of their NPO or NGO. During these lectures, specific themes within management of philanthropic organizations are highlighted and investigated.
In sum, you will gain a better understanding of:

column2: <li>
Non-profit organizations, nongovernmental and philanthropic organizations;
<li>
The management of these organizations;
<li>
The challenges these organizations are facing in the contemporary context;
<li>
The practical side of running an NPO, NGO or philanthropic organization;
<li>
The way in which the civil society sphere interacts with and is related to the business and the governmental sphere.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83098,2018,Managing People in Organisations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. JN Mell', 'HW Lam, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

There is a growing realization that organizational success and the ability of organizations to gain a competitive advantage is critically contingent on effective management of people. This course covers the mainstream topics of OB and HRM by providing ‘principles’ valuable for managers dealing with human resource issues. The course builds on BA teaching in social and psychological processes and organizational behavior, and offers an in-depth treatment of key issues in the psychology of organizational behavior. Managing People in Organizations bridges cutting-edge theory with modern leadership and managerial practices. Emphasis will be placed on examining the relationship between theory and managerial practice.

To meet course objectives, the course uses selected book chapters, articles published in international journals, lectures, and class discussion. Reading assignments (listed in the syllabus) provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class. Lectures will supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material. During the course, students are expected to actively participate in the class discussions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Explain and understand core theories in the area of organizational behavior, including job satisfaction, intelligence and selection, motivation, teams, leadership, and organizational structure.
• Apply psychological/OB theories to challenges facing current-day organizations.
• Communicate theoretically sound and practical recommendations in a persuasive manner.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80230,2018,Managing Performance of Manufacturing and Service Systems,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Roy'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The main topics to be covered include the following ones
- Developing quantitative models and estimating performance measures
- Generating system insights and improving performance

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Companies of all kinds -- manufacturing or services – believe that their customers are most important and valuable assets. Strong customer focus is often identified as the most important
differentiator between the best and the worst companies. Hence, managing customer experience and guaranteeing a certain service level is of paramount importance.

Performance management in manufacturing and service companies is often complex because the performance is affected by coordination requirements among multiple resources and the customer. To understand the objective of this course better, consider “time” as the performance measure reflecting customer experience. For instance, in a manufacturing system, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires coordination among several resources such as, supplier (providing the raw material), planner (planning the machine capacity), scheduler (scheduling the job), worker (working on machine setup), and machine (processing the job). Therefore, lower is the coordination delays among the resources, better is the performance measure positively affecting the customer experience. Likewise, in a service system such as a restaurant, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires minimizing coordination delays among the tables (seating the customer), order takers (taking the order), and kitchen resources (preparing the food). Hence, to manage manufacturing and service system performance, there is a growing importance on analyzing the system and estimating the measures that are good indicators of customer experience such as customer “waiting time.”

This course will focus on approaches to estimate the performance measures and design systems for superior performance. The complexities in managing customer performance are further increased because of the sources of uncertainties present in the system such as uncertain number of customer arrivals. The students will also learn approaches to manage system performance in the presence of business uncertainties. Through this course, the students will develop skills in building quantitative models for manufacturing and service systems, which can be analyzed rapidly to provide insights for decision making. We will also try to incorporate behavioural aspects of service and manufacturing operations in the quantitative models. The skills will be developed through a mix of concept lectures, cases, experimenting with software tools, and a course project.  Some prior exposure to simulation tools will be helpful to keep pace with the course learnings.

The students will develop analytical thinking and learn to deal with practical issues while executing the course project, develop skills for quick performance analysis of systems, and also learn to develop managerial insights from models, which is an important skill to possess for executing complex on-the-job assignments in manufacturing and service organizations. The concepts discussed in each lecture will build on the learnings from the previous lectures. Hence, the students are advised to prepare thoroughly with the course material. A detailed course outline will be posted on Canvas.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80781,2018,Managing Professional Organisations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Bogenrieder'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Professional service firms can be considered the most central change agent of our day and age: a new management theory is applied and spread by consultants, the physical environment is developed by engineers, controlling business is delegated to accountants and when all this does not succeed we rely on the help of lawyers. This indicates that professionals are ubiquitous in business life and justifies deeper research in the management of professional service organizations (PSF). In this course, we will consider professional organizations both for the ‘classical’, officially accredited professionals such as lawyers and accountants and the less ‘official’ professionals – also described as knowledge workers - such as IT experts, consultants and creative professionals in the field of marketing. We will classify them all as knowledge-intensive organizations.

The overall objective of this course is providing several perspectives on the working environment or ‘working context of a consultant’. The notion of ‘working context’ covers topics that are related to internal operations and organizational structure and processes as they are well known for professional service firms. The main question here is about the implications of working in a professional service firm. Another topic related to ‘working context’ covers methods and skills a consultant applies in a client assignment. We will provide an overview of methods as they are currently used in consultancy.

This course starts with an introductory session in the first week. During that lecture we will provide an overview of PSFs, their forms and markets and introduce interview skills and a questionnaire on PSF. Thereafter, every session in this course consists of a student presentation on the literature, followed by a discussion of the topic, formulating research questions and a final wrap-up. For the individual assignment you are asked to interview two real life consultants and use this information to write an essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80764,2018,Managing Strategy Execution,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. MH Benischke']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Many students are most likely familiar with the basic concepts of strategy. While the focus of most courses is to advance students’ understanding of strategy formulation, this core course will deepen students’ knowledge about the even more difficult process of strategy implementation (or execution).

Strategy implementation is often misunderstood. It’s “getting your hands dirty” and getting things done, but it’s more than this. It involves macro issues as well as micro issues. It involves conceptual thinking as well as routine elements. It integrates long- and short-term decisions and actions. In short, implementation covers a great deal and integrates much of what you’ll handle in your prospective managerial jobs.
The course prepares students for a managerial career through the provision of knowledge and skills relating to the management of strategy implementation processes.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To gain appreciation of the nature of strategy execution in complex organizations
<li>
To learn about the differences and connections between strategy formulation and strategy execution
<li>
To understand how organizational context and managerial decisions are interdependent and critical to the successful execution of strategy
<li>
To understand what influences firms’ ability to execute on their strategic intentions
<li>
To develop a better understanding of the challenges related to aligning central organizational dimensions

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80763,2018,Managing Strategy Formulation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'F Masihkhah', 'prof.dr. HW Volberda', 'prof.dr. JS Sidhu']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Strategic management is a well-established field of scientific inquiry and management practice. The overall objective of this course is to develop students’ theoretical understanding and practical expertise in relation to the process of strategy formulation. To achieve this objective, students will have opportunity to participate in interactive classes, and to complete team-based and individual assignments centering on the application of theoretical concepts and tools to find solutions to real-life issues practitioners face. The course prepares students for a managerial career through the provision of knowledge and skills relating to strategic leadership, use of scenario planning, management of business model innovation, and the orchestration of strategic renewal.

Teaching methods include lectures, student team-work and instructor-led discussions. Students must come prepared to each class by having read the literature and having completed the mandatory assignments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

To achieve the overall learning objective of generating proficiency regarding the management of strategy formulation process, the course’s learning sub-objectives are to develop knowledge and expertise specifically in relation to:

column2: • The nature and value of strategic management;
• Strategy formulation for enabling strategic renewal;
• Strategy formulation and business model innovation;
• Relevance of scenario planning for effective strategy formulation;
• Importance of integrating organizational learning with strategy formulation.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80222,2018,Managing innovation with alliances and acquisitions,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. K Kavusan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

As the rate of innovation increases and competition intensifies at the global level, even the largest companies require knowledge, ideas and capabilities from beyond their boundaries to develop innovations. Alliances and acquisitions are therefore becoming increasingly important corporate development activities for many companies to tap into external knowledge sources. Realizing the potential benefits of alliances and acquisitions in generating innovation outcomes is however no simple task: It is necessary to accurately evaluate of potential alliance partners and acquisition targets and different knowledge utilization strategies in terms of their suitability for a company`s innovation goals. The aim of this course is build a deep-level understanding of these issues and to provide opportunities to apply this understanding to real-life situations. The knowledge and analytical skills gained in this course will be particularly valuable for students seeking a career in high-technology industries, corporate strategy, and consulting.

The course consists of six sessions. In each session we will discuss a particular aspect of external innovation. Each session will consist of a lecture and discussion based on selected research articles related to the theme of the session, and a real-life case discussion to allow the application of research insights to real-life situations. The sessions are designed to facilitate students` contributions in the form of questions, arguments, and examples, which may lead to class-wide discussions.

Students will find opportunities to apply the knowledge and analytical skills gained in the course by working on an individual assignment, and on a group project. In these assignments, students will select a company in a high-technology industry, evaluate its innovation strategy with a particular emphasis on alliances and acquisitions, and develop an external innovation strategy with specific recommendations as to how to implement that strategy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To describe the role of alliances and acquisitions in developing innovation outcomes.
<li>
To select alliance partners and acquisition targets to achieve the innovation goals of a company.
<li>
To distinguish different strategies for utilizing external technological knowledge through alliances.
<li>
To develop an expertise in evaluating acquisition integration and its performance consequences form a technological knowledge point of view.
<li>
To develop business skills to convincingly present their ideas for innovation with alliances and acquisitions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80229,2018,Managing the Family Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. G Criaco', 'M Leusder, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Family businesses are the most common form of business organization in almost all countries and industries worldwide. This is true not only for small, private companies. Founders or founding families are important controlling owners of large corporations listed on stock exchanges around the world. Famous examples of family businesses are IKEA, Harley Davidson and Heineken. As such, family businesses represent a very important force for the economic and social development anywhere in the world. Family control, however, raises unique challenges as well as value-creating opportunities for family businesses and their different stakeholders, such as customers, financiers, suppliers, partners, employees, board members and owners.

This course introduces students to the widespread, yet complex, phenomenon of family business. It touches upon several important themes, such as strategy development, succession, governance, conflicts, continuation, and more. The aim of the course is to introduce concepts and practical learning situations which may help the students to make sense of family businesses and to assist them in understanding and dealing with the challenges and opportunities faced by different family business stakeholders.

The course is specially designed for those who are interested in working in family businesses (e.g., as owner and/or manager) or with family businesses (e.g., as advisor and consultant), and for those coming from a family business background. Whatever their future role, students will find it useful to understand the uniqueness of these companies. During the course, the students will develop their own perspective on family businesses. After the course, the students should be able to apply in practice appropriate models and theories presented during the course, as well as critically examine models and theories regarding family business development.

The teaching methods used in this course consist of lectures, cases, group discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come to each session very well-prepared by having read the required readings and case for the session. Attendance at all classes is mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of the course, the student will be able to:

column2: <li>
Demonstrate knowledge about common characteristics and challenges of family businesses
<li>
Describe the main theories and concepts within the field of family business research and practice
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to analyze and apply family business theories and concepts to different critical situations in family businesses
<li>
Critically evaluate the use of concepts and models used to understand family businesses
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to reflect upon common challenges facing family businesses in practice, and develop a way to address these challenges

column1: In addition to these content-specific objectives, the student will be able to:

column2: <li>
Demonstrate an ability to work with others in a professional manner while attempting to achieve a common goal
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to think critically by identifying, analyzing and providing concrete solutions to complex problems, both in a team and individually

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80782,2018,Managing the Supply Chain,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. Q Kong', 'dr. T Lu', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company; in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process; furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.
To pass this core course, a participant needs to:

column2: <li>
Participate actively in class;
<li>
Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade);
<li>
Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:

column2: <li>
Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
<li>
Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations
<li>

Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
<li>
Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
<li>
Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
<li>
Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
<li>
Enhance your team working and project management skills

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master's thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

column2: • discussion of literature  as  an introduction to  the theme
• design of a research proposal
• one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
• carrying  out research
• critical discussion of the  research  proposals
• discussion of and  information on possible  research methods
• discussion of empirical research  and other  work  in progress
• one-on-one  progress  meetings  with  thesis supervisor
• wrapping  up research
• discussion of empirical research  and other  work  in progress
• one-on-one  progress  meetings  with  thesis supervisor
• presentation of the  thesis  research at master  conference  in June 2019
• participation in discussions following presentations The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.

column1: In the 19th century, the introduction of steam power and the electronic telegraph changed the world dramatically. The transfer of goods, passengers, and information accelerated, connecting people worldwide who had never been linked before. These changes had a massive impact, economically, socially and culturally. After World War II and in the late 20th century similar developments occurred, inciting the next stages of globalisation.

The impressive developments of both periods as well as their dramatic consequences are the central theme of the course. The focus will be on port cities, their maritime connections with the wider world overseas and their international relation with the hinterland. The port of Rotterdam will serve as the Dutch example. Singapore, New York, Shanghai, London, Hamburg, Antwerp or any other maritime hub may act as its international parallel.

Typical topics to discuss will be: competition and technological and organisational innovation;  labor protest and trade unions; life on board for crew and passengers; exploration; the military positions of the powers on the seas; safety and piracy; the impact of migration; and decreasing transport costs  as  well as  the  cultural reflection of these changes in art and literature. In their research, students will draw upon the collection of the Maritime Museum Rotterdam, analyzing artefacts in addition to written sources.

In the Research Workshop students learn how to structure and conduct historical research adequately and efficiently. The tutorial classes focus on the critical assessment and discussion of the research design, data collection, and methodology. In addition, much consideration is given to the analysis, reporting, and presentation of research findings. Students present their ideas and work-in- progress and learn how to contribute in a constructive way to the research of their peers.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report, and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers
