<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. Your lecturer will provide you with a systematic framework for understanding marketing management and strategy.

How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace?  How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • Define the concept of marketing;
• Understand the fundamental principles of marketing, the key elements in developing and planning a marketing strategy, and the determinants of consumer behaviour;
• Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts;
• Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings;
• Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories;
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80800,2018,Marketing,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. GH van Bruggen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies develop a competitive advantage according to the marketing concept?”. Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

As said, the course will be taught via a blend of lectures and case discussions. During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight implementational issues.

During the case discussions, you will be expected to analyze realistic problem situations in the form of business cases. As in actual practice, these cases are characterized by a limited time frame for making decisions, incomplete information, and no clear ""best"" answer. The case method is essential to developing the kind of problem-solving and communication skills highly valued in the managerial practice. The ability to generalize from the specific case situations discussed in class to new situations that you may encounter is one of the foundations of management education.

During case discussions, a poorly prepared class invariably leads to an unrewarding experience for all involved. Thus, the long-term benefits from this course will be proportional to the extent that you make this course your project. This means that you are expected to come to class prepared and to actively participate. Specifically, you are expected to contribute to an informed exchange about the topic of the class and to have well-developed points of view about the cases and other reading material.
For the case assignments,You are expected to form and work in a 4-person team. Also you are expected to work in the same team for both cases.

A case is a description of a set of events or situations in an organization in which something is currently or potentially problematic. The task of the case analyst (i.e., you) is to diagnose and analyze the case problems and answer the case question(s). For each case, the questions need to be answered before the class starts. There are many ways to approach the case questions. The suggested, but not mandatory process for case analysis is:

column2: <li>
Read the case carefully. Use exhibits to help you understand and/or interpret the text
<li>
With the case analysis in mind, discuss the case questions and possible answers with your team member
<li>
Decide how you will present your answers to the case questions
<li>
Write up the answers to the case questions
<li>
Make sure your recommendation follows from a systematic analysis of the available materials
<li>
Make sure you do not only use the materials/information that support your point of view but also take so-called “disconfirming” evidence into account.

column1: The answers to the case questions should be no longer than 5 single-spaced, typewritten pages excluding tables, exhibits, and bibliography (references are fine; endnotes/footnotes are not allowed). Leave one-inch margins on all four sides and use a font size no smaller than 12 characters per inch. All case answers need to be in English and need to be handed in on paper before the start of class in which the case discussion is programmed. Materials that are handed in later cannot be graded.

During the case discussions we will discuss the questions you have answered. However, other questions will be discussed as well. It is, therefore, necessary to read the case really well before you come to class and be prepared to participate in the discussion on any kind of question regarding the case.

The pedagogical value of this assignment is compromised when students access external information, instead of relying exclusively on the documentation provided. To highlight specific issues, facts may be distorted and important situational factors might be omitted. Therefore, for the cases you are not expected to do any library work or bring in outside information about the company or the industry beyond what is described in the case. All of our discussions will be based on the assumption that we are dealing with the problems of the company at the time of the case and in addressing the questions only information that is in the case description should be used.
The quality of your answers to the case questions will be judged on the basis of:

column2: <li>
The clarity and precision of the answers.
<li>
The use and application of relevant marketing concepts in answering the questions.
<li>
The extent to which the answers are supported by logic and by reference to specific case information.
<li>
The appropriateness of the answers.
<li>
Overall organization, as well as clarity and quality of writing.

column1: Case grades will be communicated through Sin Online at the end of the course but before the exam. In case you do not hand in a case analysis you will receive the grade 1 for that specific case.

Marketing management is not a “hard science”. There are, however, a number of theories and concepts that you need to master in order to understand and manage marketing. You will be asked to demonstrate your competences in an exam that consists of a series of open questions. The exam will be a “closed-book” exam and will cover all the materials that have been discussed during lectures, case discussions and that have been made available through Canvas. Please check SIN Online for the exact timing of the exam and the resit.

All information about the course will be communicated through Canvas. Please check regularly for announcements. Powerpoint handouts of the classes will also be made available through Canvas. This will be done after the class.
A reading list with articles is part of the course materials. All articles assigned as readings are exam materials.
This course is worth 4 ECTS (2 foundation ECTS and 2 master ECTS).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing management. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge for making decisions at the business level and developing an appreciation for the inter-disciplinary nature of marketing strategy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Tijdens dit vak werken studenten in teams samen om een marketing plan te maken voor een nieuw product of dienst. Ze krijgen informatie over de verschillende componenten van het marketing plan door middel van webcasts en een op maat gemaakt digitaal boek. Daarnaast krijgen de studenten voorbeelden te zien over hoe bedrijven de verschillende marketing concepten in de praktijk gebruiken. Dit gebeurt aan de hand van casestudies en gastcolleges van top marketing managers van internationale bedrijven. Studenten krijgen regelmatig feedback op de voortgang van hun marketing plan. Een tussentoets en een eindtentamen toetsen de studenten op de kennis en de toepassing van kennis van de verschillende marketing concepten.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

“Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that rely on data to improve marketing decisions. As the amount of data available to even the smallest companies continues to increase, companies of all types will continue to embrace this exciting and growing field.

Marketing analysts need to possess a diverse skill set. Although experience with programming and statistics is important, technical skills alone are typically not sufficient for success. Analysts must understand the business context they work in so that they can sensibly interpret results. Furthermore, marketing analysts must be able to clearly and persuasively communicate their insights to managers.

This course provides hands-on opportunities for you to develop and integrate these diverse skills. In the first half of the course, we emphasize the technical—reinforcing skills obtained from previous courses (e.g., statistical analysis of data, multiple regression) and developing new ones (e.g., advanced data visualization, demand estimation). In the second half of the course, we emphasize the application of these skills to solve managerial problems and communicate a recommended course of action.
Topics covered include the following (and are subject to change):
Week 1: Review of probability and statistics, and OLS regression; binary logistic regression; programming in R
Week 2: Designing and interpreting choice-based conjoint experiments; extending these ideas to estimate preferences and market shares using panel data; programming in R
Week 3: Psychological principles for data visualization and the grammar of graphics; using R’s ggplot2 package to visualize data and gain new insights
Week 4: Estimating the total market potential for new products with limited data; estimating consumer preferences using aggregated market data; manipulating, summarizing, and cleaning data in R

Weeks 5-6: Various topics in advanced market research, including: customer segmentation via statistical clustering; estimating customer lifetime value; introductory concepts in machine learning and forecasting, mining data from the web and social media, text-based sentiment analysis

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind basic statistical concepts, as well as more advanced topics
<li>
Manipulate and summarize data using R (statistical software: see www.r-project.org)
<li>
Draw inferences from data in order to answer questions relevant to marketing managers
<li>
Use R to graphically represent data and inferences; recognize and evaluate alternative presentation strategies
<li>
Explain and justify managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through written reports

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81057,2018,Marketing Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. V Morea', 'L Marques', 'UZ Birsel - Birsel']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations need to generate more income from private sources such as ticket sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, e.g., having a clear and appealing identity, communicating and bonding effectively with their audiences, or offering arrangements attracting new audiences. Thus, arts organizations need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. Marketing is an indispensable tool to shape the relation with the public into a meaningful mutual commitment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will introduce students to the principles of art marketing. On the one hand, students will learn which characteristics of potential audience members determine their interest in the arts and how this interest may be increased. On the other hand, students are introduced to marketing strategies employed by cultural organizations and the rationale behind them.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83386,2018,Marketing Beyond Borders: Managing Cross Cultural Challenges,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AK Klesse'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the twenty-first century, the market growth of well-developed and affluent countries has slowed and more and more companies turn(ed) toward emerging markets where the potential is much bigger. Within emerging markets, companies shift their attention from the affluent society to the growing middle class. These changes confront companies with the challenge of operating and competing in very different markets and targeting various consumer segments with heterogeneous needs and preferences. Notably, several large multinational firms have seen their profits decline because they ignored the influence of culture, centralized their marketing, and lacked an understanding of local differences (De Mooij and Hofstede 2002).

This course provides you with a solid understanding of cross-cultural differences and their impact on marketing strategy in an attempt to prepare you for a professional career as a Global Product/Brand Manager (or related functions). We will get to know several cultural frameworks, utilize them to predict consumer behavior, and derive important managerial implications for various Marketing activities (such as Marketing research or branding). To assure high practical relevance, this course incorporates a team assignment with a multi-national company: you will work (in teams) on a real-life problem/challenge and present your findings to the company during a presentation day.

Notably, this course differs from other Marketing courses (e.g., Marketing strategy or Consumer Behavior) in its strong focus on cross-cultural differences; we will emphasize the challenges and problems that arise when applying established marketing concepts (with or without adaptation) in various different (developed and emerging) markets.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Understand how cultural profiles can be used to predict differences in consumer behavior across markets
• Be able to define Global Marketing Strategy and distinguish between different perspectives (e.g., standardization/adaptation, configuration and integration of value chain)
• Recognize cross-cultural challenges that arise when companies operate beyond borders for various Marketing domains (e.g., Marketing research or Branding)
• Get to know different strategies that companies apply to globalize; understand their advantages and challenges
• Understand how (and which) cross-cultural differences could impact consumer behavior and then develop corresponding managerial implications
• Develop a marketing strategy for existing products/brands for a specific market (real life business case)

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80853,2018,Marketing Honours Class,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AK Klesse', 'dr. B Van den Bergh']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A limited group of 20-25 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd and 4th block of their studies. During the sessions, faculty members and marketing practitioners will discuss relevant and current themes in marketing, such as branding and social media.

Researchers within the department will present their own and others’ latest research in these areas and discuss it with the students. Practitioners and alumni will be invited to some of the sessions to give the programme a more applied flavour. The programme will also feature company visits. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation consisting of reading and summarizing relevant literature. Cooperation will be sought with external partners, who will discuss the topics from their practical perspective.

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Marketing Management. The first step in the selection process will be a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS). In the second step in the selection process, the highest ranking students will be asked to submit a motivation letter.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The honours class in Marketing Management puts excellent marketing students in close contact with the latest advancements in marketing science and practice. The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also designed to facilitate the transition from marketing student to marketing practitioner by offering ample networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80616,2018,Marketing Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Genevsky'],,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytic and synthetic skills. This course introduces a set of frameworks and tools which can be used to solve general business problems as well as to develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific.  The course is centred on understanding the 3Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) using the STP (segmentation, targeting, and positioning), and translating that strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the 4Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and distribution). </mystyle></body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis.  In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses and discussion in class will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in simulated business contexts and (2) provide an opportunity (both written and oral) to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.
At the end of this course the student should have obtained the following skills:

column2: • Familiarity with foundational concepts of modern Marketing Management;
• Ability to develop a coherent marketing plan;
• Succinctly communicate a marketing plan on paper;
• Analyse a complex business case with a small group of colleagues;
• The use of several analytical tools, including tools used in segmentation and targeting;
• The ability to apply marketing concepts across a diverse set of contexts

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders. This course will help you to develop an in-depth understanding of key frameworks, concepts, and paradigms in marketing strategy and, just as important, to develop skills in the application of this knowledge. We will focus on two strategic problems, competitive positioning and innovation, and on two substantive areas, sustainability and technology. At a general level, the basic goal of this course is to help you make the transition from student to marketing practitioner and thus support your own goal of becoming a successful marketing professional. During the course, you will train extensively your case solving skills both in class, during interactive case discussions, and individually, in the assignments and trial exams. Student participation during the interactive lectures and meaningful contributions to the case discussions are essential. To facilitate interaction, the group will be split into three sections for some of the classes. Students will be tested by means of an exam and written case assignments (both individual and group).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: <li>
Understand how the context of marketing strategy is changing
<li>
Determine an organization’s competitive position
<li>
Recognize sources of meaningful differentiation
<li>
Understand how companies can become more innovative
<li>
Recognize potential ethical issues in marketing practice

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80749,2018,Marketing Strategy Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. X Chen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will focus on quantitative aspects of marketing research and how using quantitative tools can help managers address substantive marketing problems such as new product design, market segmentation and positioning. Also, the course aims to enhance students' understanding of how marketing variables such as price, advertising and sales force affect market share and sales, and how to develop marketing strategies based on quantitative analysis. Using a blended learning approach, the course tries to balance technicalities with marketing insights. Overall, the course is intended to make students well-informed users of marketing research, not becoming methodological experts.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To appreciate and understand the potential contributions of marketing strategy research models to marketing decisions.
<li>
Be able to translate marketing management problems into appropriate marketing strategy research models.
<li>
To develop a critical eye for marketing research, being able to judge strengths and weaknesses of marketing strategy models.
<li>
Have a working “hands-on” experience with marketing strategy research techniques.
<li>
Be able to use (multivariate) statistical methods to support strategic marketing decisions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven handelen namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe Marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staat. We bekijken hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het met succes afronden van dit vak:

column2: • Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren hoe marketing een “force for positive change” kan zijn door het creëren van lange-termijn waarde voor klanten, bedrijven en de maatschappij in het algemeen;
• Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren waarom en hoe marketing een centraal deel is van een organisatiestrategie door middel van waarde creatie voor de relevante stakeholders;

• Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren waarom, met het oog op het vinden van nieuwe opportuniteiten voor waarde creatie, het van cruciaal belang is dat organisaties de relevante stakeholders, micro/macro-omgevingsfactoren en trends moeten identificeren en in het oog houden;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de centrale tactische elementen van marketing management;
• Bent u in staat om te consumentenmotivaties, behoeften en beslissingsroutes te identificeren en te begrijpen.

• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden die illustratief zijn van marketing theorie of duiden op problemen met een marketingstrategie te identificeren, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.
• Kan u samenwerken aan een marketing case met een kleine groep van collega’s en uw conclusies beargumenteren in een rapport.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80197,2018,Marketing of New Products,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. YM van Everdingen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

New products, also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. For example, why had Grolsch to withdraw the Cheersch home beer draft system from the market, while competing products, such as the PerfectDraft or the Beertender are still being sold? And, why did Nintendo’s Wii U never catch up with Nintendo’s projected sales shortly after the introduction? In contrast, what explains the success of a service like Airbnb or the Pokemon Go game. Within two weeks after its introduction, the game had 40 million daily active users. In other words, what makes one new product successful, while another new product fails to recoup its R&D cost? This question will be central in this course, and will be discussed form two angles, i.e., new product launch, and acceptance in the market.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption and diffusion of new products in the market place, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Select the most appropriate launch strategy for different types of new products, both for the domestic and the global market;
<li>
Understand both the consumer’s and the retailer’s new product adoption decision process;
<li>
Understand the diffusion process and the application of diffusion models across countries
<li>
Forecast the future sales of new products and the likelihood of a successful launch.

<body>The Master Thesis Class trains students in developing a research proposal and conducting research on their own research subject. This is done through a series of class meetings and workshops in term 1, 2, and 3 of the academic year. The meetings cover different subjects and phases of the research process. As such the Master Thesis Class supports students in developing, conducting and reporting on the Master Thesis research project with which they will conclude their Master's degree programme.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the  relationship between the  research question, theory, data  and analysis, and how to  integrate  these  elements  into  a  well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students build their proposal through consecutive assignments. There is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, the meetings serve as regular collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In the meetings, the emphasis is on the general requirements and possible hurdles. In doing so, ample attention is paid to the content-related and formal criteria, as well as the time planning, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements.  Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, argumentation, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, including an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search for, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81785,2018,Master Thesis Class PTC,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfil as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between place, culture and tourism that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design.  Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, focusing on the intertwined relationship between place, culture and tourism. This includes an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.

In order to complete the Master of HEPL, with specialisation Health Economics, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HEPL Master. The combined workload of the Thesis Plan and Thesis is 16 ECTS (or 448 hours) and thus constitutes a major part of the curriculum. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HEPL staff. The evaluation of the thesis and defence for the final grade is conducted by the student's thesis reading committee, which includes the supervisor and one co-evaluator. The co-evaluator must be someone from the ESHPM or ESE staff.
More information regarding the HE thesis, the graduation procedure, and a link to the coursebook can be found at https://www.eur.nl/ese/english/information_for/students/master_students/master_

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this Academic Skills Course students will guided towards the actual writing of their thesis in block 4. The course consists of four tutorials sessions, three milestones and thesis writing circle meetings. In the first tutorial session students are stimulated by means of brainstorm sessions to come up with a preliminary thesis topic. In the second session two members of the faculty staff will give practical information about doing research. ‘How to write and cite’ is addressed in the third session. During the last session students will give a short presentation of their thesis and research. Afterwards feedback will be given by other students and lecturers. Instructions for the three milestone assignments will be given during the tutorial sessions. After the last tutorial sessions students will form separate thesis circles under the supervision of a tutor.</body>

column2: • Preparation for the Master’s thesis

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The principal objective of the Master thesis is to familiarise students with carrying out business and management research and to allow students to gain a deeper understanding of a topic of their interest. As such, the thesis contributes to the student’s specialisation in a particular area. Knowledge and understanding of business and management research is relevant in both business and academic settings. Training in business research methods prepares students to systematically investigate and solve a management dilemma (i.e., any problem or opportunity that requires a management decision) and to evaluate whether studies and proposals prepared by third parties (e.g. consultancy agencies) can serve as a basis for a management decision.

Through the Master thesis process students will also develop their competencies and skills in writing and communicating their ideas. Finally, time management and self-management are important managerial skills, which the thesis period provides an excellent opportunity to develop and test.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>During this course, students learn about the structure of a master thesis and about the available master thesis topics. Students obtain comprehensive guidance in an information and Q&A session before they select their topic. During and after the session, students can ask questions as well as ask for additional advice. After the orientation session, students select their master thesis topic from the topic list, read the recommended literature and independently prepare a draft of their research idea (max 3 pages), which has to be submitted to the coach. The research idea can be based either on the pre-defined questions indicated in the topic description or on own ideas within the indicated topics, depending on the capabilities, creativity and ambition of the individual students. During the meeting, the coach provides the student with feedback on the research idea, which students have to incorporate. Students have to hand in a document containing the introduction and literature review chapters of the thesis. Students pass this stage if this document is of sufficient quality.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students should be able to

column2: • summarize the literature relevant to the chosen master thesis topic;
• identify one or more gaps in the literature;
• formulate research questions to address the identified gap(s) in the literature;
• explain the contribution of the proposed research to the literature;
• describe
• identify the methods and data sources necessary to conduct the proposed research;
• write an introduction and literature review containing all of the above elements.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<div>Het schrijven van de master thesis staat centraal tijdens de masteropleiding. In de master thesis laten studenten zien dat zij op basis van eigen, oorspronkelijk onderzoek een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan het wetenschappelijke debat over een bepaald onderwerp uit het eigen vakgebied. Overige eisen die  worden gesteld aan de  master thesis zijn:

column2: • het onderzoek is gebaseerd op een helder geformuleerde probleemstelling en daaruit afgeleide onderzoeksvragen;
• het onderzoek is gestoeld op theorieën en methoden uit het vakgebied, dan wel theorieën en

column1: methoden die  voor  dit specifieke  onderwerp relevant zijn;

column2: • deze theorieën en methoden worden in de thesis besproken en beargumenteerd ten aanzien van de probleemstelling;
• eerder  onderzoek rond het gekozen onderwerp wordt aangegeven, samengevat en besproken

column1: voorzover  relevant voor  het eigen onderzoek;

column2: • gebruikte literatuur, primaire en secundaire bronnen, overige gegevens en data worden systematisch gepresenteerd en aan elkaar gerelateerd;
• het onderzoek mondt uit in een heldere, bondig  geschreven conclusie;
• de  thesis  bestaat uit een inleiding, diverse hoofdstukken waarin de bevindingen worden besproken,
• literatuur, bronnen en overige gegevens en data worden nauwkeurig opgegeven in voetnoten, eventueel in aparte bijlagen;
• de  thesis is geschreven in verzorgd en accuraat Nederlands of Engels;
• de thesis kent een omvang van ca. 25.000 woorden (ca. 50 pagina’s van 500 woorden). Het maximum is 30.000 woorden, exclusief titelblad, inhoudsopgave, voorwoord en bijlagen

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Het formuleren van een wetenschappelijk en maatschappelijk relevante vraagstelling op het gebied van media en communicatie.
• Het ontwikkelen van een passende onderzoeksopzet.
• Het organiseren en uitvoeren van het onderzoek.
• Het adequaat toepassen van gangbare methoden en technieken voor de verzameling en analyse van gegevens.
• Het rapporteren van hun onderzoek en hun bevindingen op een samenhangende en zelfkritische wijze.
• Het reflecteren op de  wetenschappelijke  en maatschappelijke implicaties van hun onderzoek.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:

column2: • the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions;
• the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme;
• the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
• the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated;
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.

column1: The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:

column2: • the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s); a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s); an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis; a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic;
• the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices;
• the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words;
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
• the article will be written in polished, accurate English;
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Through writing the thesis the student demonstrates that she/he is able to:

column2: • independently formulate an original and relevant scholarly problem in his or her field of study;
• draw up an appropriate research proposal, including a positioning of the thesis in currently scholarly discussion, a well-argued research strategy, and time plan.
• organise the research set-up (empirical and/or fieldwork research);
• use current social-scientific methods and techniques to collect and analyse the required information and data;
• report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way;
• evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process;
• write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: De masterscriptie is de afsluiting en tevens de bekroning van de master Sociologie. Het scriptietraject valt uiteen in twee delen, namelijk de scriptie-opzet en het scriptieonderzoek. Beide delen vinden plaats in groepsprojecten (maximaal 5 studenten). De scriptie-opzet heeft tot doel dat de student onder begeleiding van een docent zijn of haar eigen scriptieopzet ontwikkelt en uitschrijft. Een voldoende beoordeling van de scriptie-opzet is de voorwaarde om een start te kunnen maken met de uitvoering van het scriptieonderzoek. In dit tweede deel van de scriptie vindt de uitvoering van het onderzoek en de verslaglegging plaats.

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: Tijdens het schrijven van de scriptie-opzet en de uitvoering en verslaglegging van het scriptie-onderzoek leert de student:

column5: Een adequate en sociologisch relevante doel- en probleemstelling te formuleren;
Beschrijvende en verklarende vragen te onderscheiden;
Sociologische theorie en onderzoeksbevindingen op functionele wijze te benutten mede door daar hypothesen of kwalitatieve onderzoeksvragen van af te leiden.
Een overzicht van bestaande literatuur op het gekozen gebied te maken, uitmondend in een gepreciseerde vraagstelling voor het eigen scriptieonderzoek;
Een bij de vraagstelling passend onderzoeksdesign te ontwerpen
De praktische haalbaarheid van een onderzoek te bepalen.
Op een verantwoorde wijze concepten te operationaliseren.
Zelfstandig empirisch onderzoek uit te voeren op secundaire of zelf-verzamelde data, daarbij gebruikmakend van de relevante methoden en technieken voor sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek.
De sociologisch-theoretische waarde van haar/zijn onderzoeksbevindingen, alsmede de beleidsrelevantie daarvan.
Onderzoeksresultaten helder en logisch te rapporteren en te communiceren.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the MGN courses and topics. The thesis must  have an a recognizible  governance topic as research object and focused on analyzing this governance topic

Note that an internship is not part of the MGN program (but in special cases it is possible to include this. But this always needs a positive decision of the supervisors of the master program). .At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, who will very often be one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the MGN program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors. After the manuscript has been approved by the supervisor, he or she will involve a second reader. When both approve the research project and all requirements of the MGN master have been satisfied, the thesis will be defended in front of the delegated examination board.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The master thesis demonstrates that students are able:
•        to define a clear research question;
•        to indicate its social and theoretical relevance;
•        to develop a clearly defined theoretical framework;
•        to operationalize concepts into reliable and valid indicators;
•        to choose and defend appropriate methods of data collection and to actually collect relevant and reliable data;
•        to choose and defend appropriate methods of data analysis and to analyze data systematically;
•        to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research;
•        to clearly structure and fully reference a research report.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De masterclasses worden verzorgd door de partners die verbonden zijn aan Toga aan de Maas. Ze vinden plaats aan de Erasmus School of Law of inhouse bij de parnters. Soms zullen de studenten uit publiekrechtelijke hoek samen met de privaatrechtelijk studenten deelnemen aan de masterclasses. Gedurende deze masterclasses zal op belangrijke leerstukken worden ingegaan vanuit rechtsvergelijkend perspectief. Zo kan er vanuit verschillende perspectieven bekeken worden hoe frauderende bestuurders aansprakelijk gesteld kunnen worden. Fiscaal gezien werkt dit natuurlijk anders uit dan strafrechtelijk. Studenten die deelnemen aan het programma van Toga aan de Maas worden geacht problemen te signaleren en bekijken vanuit verschillende invalshoeken. Ook kunnen de studenten masterclasses volgen die meer zijn toegespitst op hun achtergrond.  Op deze manier wordt de voor een excellente master typische verdieping aangebracht binnen de privaatrechtelijke en binnen de publiekrechtelijke vakken.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Aanleren van specifieke toga vaardigheden
• Verdieping in gerichte ethiek (concrete dillema's)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81420,2018,Masterclass actualiteiten gezondheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['M.A.J.M. Buijsen', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak wordt het onderwijs primair verzorgd door gerenommeerde juristen (advocaten, ziekenhuisjuristen, etc.) werkzaam in de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht. Zij laten de studenten kennismaken met actuele ontwikkelingen op de verschillende deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied: het zorgverleningsrecht, het zorgverzekeringsrecht en het zorginkooprecht. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd hun eerder opgedane kennis van deze deelgebieden van het gezondheidsrecht toe te passen op actuele vraagstukken. De studenten krijgen van de gastdocenten casuïstiek voorgelegd, die zij moeten behandelen in wekelijks in te leveren werkstukken. De rechtsvragen die de studenten krijgen voorgelegd, zijn ontleend aan die van de rechtspraktijk van de gastdocenten. Het onderwijs vindt deels plaats ten kantore van de praktijkjuristen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Doel/Purpose:

• De student heeft kennisgemaakt met de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht en de laatste ontwikkelingen op alle deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied. Hij heeft weet van de relevante rechtspraak en nieuwe ontwikkelingen op deze terreinen en is in staat om deze ontwikkelingen te kunnen plaatsen en op hun relevantie te kunnen beoordelen.

• De student beschikt over juridische en algemene academische vaardigheden, waarbij kennis van het gezondheidsrecht, inzicht en probleemoplossende vermogens kunnen worden toegepast in nieuwe of onbekende omstandigheden binnen de bredere (of multidisciplinaire) context van dit rechtsgebied.
• Dit betekent dat
• de student wet- en regelgeving op casuïstiek kan toepassen en een logisch antwoord kan formuleren op de rechtsvragen bij een casus.
• de student op basis van een actuele casus de rechtsvraag kan formuleren;
• De student geeft bij het doen van de praktijkopdrachten blijk van creativiteit en zelfstandigheid.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80189,2018,Mastering Networks for Innovation,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Tasselli'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Social network connections and positions constrain and facilitate outcomes of importance to individuals, groups, and organizations. For instance, Networks and relationships are not only critical to access and exchange information and resources but also imperative to organize support and to market innovative ideas.

In the lectures of this course we focus on social networks and relationships more generally and on when and how they influence innovation in particular. We address different network structures (e.g., size, tie strength, centrality, or density) across different levels (e.g., individual-, dyadic-, team-, or organizational-level) in different innovation phases (e.g., idea generation, implementation, or diffusion). Furthermore, we discuss important differences between online and offline social networks and explore the general drivers and antecedents of social networks and relationships.
In workshops you get familiar with the UCINET and NetDraw software. These are tools that help you analyze and visualize social networks.

In a project that is run in co-operation with an organization, you will apply the insights of this course to craft a strategy that utilizes the power of social networks and you will give adcice on how the network should and could be developed in the furture.

The learnings of this course are especially relevant for prospective consultants and innovation managers who need to analyze and shape change processes and intra- or inter-organizational collaboration projects. For students interested in examining, understanding, and optimizing their network position and structure, the learnings are of equal use.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
You will get equipped with the latest insights and theories on the drivers and consequences of social networks for innovation.
<li>
You will learn state-of-the-art tools to analyse and visualize social networks.
• You will understand the advantages and disadvantages that certain positions in a network have.
• You will be able to give advice about the changes that are necessary to take full advantage of a network position.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81628,2018,Materieel strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['MH Bahreman', 'MJ Davarci, LLM', 'mr. B de Jong', 'mr. C Mannee', 'mr. CL van der Vis', 'mr. M Kooijmans', 'mr.dr.drs. L Postma', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr. S Struijk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak. Daarnaast oefent de student tijdens de practicumbijeenkomsten met het mondeling bepleiten van een materieel strafrechtelijke casus.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1. de beginselen, leerstukken en systematiek van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, herkennen, definiëren, analyseren en beoordelen;
2. theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, verklaren en analyseren;
3. verschillende materieel strafrechtelijke begrippen onderscheiden, analyseren en beargumenteerd toepassen op een concrete strafrechtelijke casus;

4. beoordelen welk materieel strafrechtelijk leerstuk in een concreet geval van toepassing is en motiveren of aan de in de huidige relevante wetsbepalingen, literatuur en jurisprudentie gestelde voorwaarden is voldaan, en;
5. de daarvoor relevante jurisprudentie opzoeken, analyseren, toepassen en in onderling verband kritisch beoordelen;
6. een argumentatief juridisch betoog inzake een materieel strafrechtelijke casus mondeling binnen een bepaalde tijdspanne bepleiten en presenteren.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81674,2018,Materieel strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['LW Lagaaij, LLM', 'MJ Davarci, LLM', 'mr. B de Jong', 'mr. M Kooijmans', 'mr.dr.drs. L Postma', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr. S Struijk', 'S van den Heuvel, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak. Daarnaast oefent de student tijdens de practicumbijeenkomsten met het mondeling bepleiten van een materieel strafrechtelijke casus.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1. de beginselen, leerstukken en systematiek van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, herkennen, definiëren, analyseren en beoordelen;
2. theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, verklaren en analyseren;
3. verschillende materieel strafrechtelijke begrippen onderscheiden, analyseren en beargumenteerd toepassen op een concrete strafrechtelijke casus;

4. beoordelen welk materieel strafrechtelijk leerstuk in een concreet geval van toepassing is en motiveren of aan de in de huidige relevante wetsbepalingen, literatuur en jurisprudentie gestelde voorwaarden is voldaan, en;
5. de daarvoor relevante jurisprudentie opzoeken, analyseren, toepassen en in onderling verband kritisch beoordelen;
6. een argumentatief juridisch betoog inzake een materieel strafrechtelijke casus mondeling binnen een bepaalde tijdspanne bepleiten en presenteren.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In dat vak zijn de grote lijnen van ‘het strafrecht’ uiteengezet. Daarbij heeft de student kennisgemaakt met twee deelgebieden van het strafrecht, te weten het materiële strafrecht en het strafprocesrecht. In het onderhavige vak staat enkel het eerstgenoemd deelgebied centraal en wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden.

Tijdens het vak doet de student niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken. Dat betekent dat naast het actief op zoek gaan naar relevante literatuur, het bestuderen van deze literatuur en het discussiëren daarover, ook vaardigheden als het oplossen van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek), belangrijke onderdelen van het vak vormen. Daarnaast staat in het vaardighedenonderwijs voor dit vak specifiek de mondelinge pleitvaardigheid centraal. Daartoe zal de student tijdens de practicumbijeenkomsten oefenen met het mondeling bepleiten van een materieel strafrechtelijke casus.</body>

column3: Na dit vak kan de student:
1. de beginselen, leerstukken en systematiek van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, herkennen, definiëren, analyseren en beoordelen;
2. theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, verklaren en analyseren;
3. verschillende materieel strafrechtelijke begrippen onderscheiden, analyseren en beargumenteerd toepassen op een concrete strafrechtelijke casus;

4. beoordelen welk materieel strafrechtelijk leerstuk in een concreet geval van toepassing is en motiveren of aan de in de huidige relevante wetsbepalingen, literatuur en jurisprudentie gestelde voorwaarden is voldaan, en;
5. de daarvoor relevante jurisprudentie opzoeken, analyseren, toepassen en in onderling verband kritisch beoordelen;
6. Een argumentatief juridisch betoog inzake een materieel strafrechtelijke casus mondeling binnen een bepaalde tijdspanne bepleiten en presenteren.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82195,2018,Measurement of Patient Preferences using Discrete Choice Experiments,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. MF Jonker'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences for health care products and programs are also shaped by non-health outcomes (such as amount of information) and process attributes (such as treatment location, or route of drug administration). Studies into these outcomes beyond health are an emerging trend in HTA and health economics. Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCE allows investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit, which gives this method the flexibility to include any concern deemed of relevance. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory underlying DCEs, demonstrate the process of carrying out a choice study, and discuss the policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and work groups, but students will also be actively involved in a DCE study with the aim to increase understanding of what is taught more quickly. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The groups complete their work step by step over several weeks. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE; individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.
The written examination is 70% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%) and a group project (30%).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • recognize the importance of patient preference measurements in health care
• describe the theoretical foundation(s) of discrete choice experiments (DCEs)
• develop their own DCE using state-of-the-art (publishable) methods
• understand recent articles in the DCE literature and assess the validity of the presented conclusions
