<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Many individuals use many forms of media for many hours every day of their lives. In this course, we examine the effects that can be observed in different media audiences and their uses and influence of media on daily life. The topics covered here address entertainment, mood changes, attitudes, behaviors, and procrastination, as each relates to media. Examples are: The Buffy effect, propaganda, hedonic and eudamonic entertainment, influencers, and differences in Facebook usage. In addition to reading contemporary communication and media research and contributing to class discussions, students maintain media use diaries to think critically, socially, and personally about their own media use and how media affects them. We will have short weekly assignments to assure that all students prepared and reflected on theories and findings as well as media effects they perceive in daily life.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and an understanding of:

column2: • Major theoretical approaches to media audiences and effects;
• Audience members´ uses and interpretations of media;
• Media use and the influence on knowledge, attitudes, and impression formation.
• Critically reflect upon media effects and instances of non-effects.
• Reflect on media content by applying theories and research findings

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81233,2018,Media Campaigns,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This seminar addresses the theory and practice of media campaigns as well as processes that drive the planning and execution of these campaigns and the role of the latest technological advancements in campaigning. Students will review theories and research on segmentation, media use and persuasion and will analyze real-world media campaigns by drawing on the theoretical and research articles covered in the course.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on media campaigns
• The role and use of (different) media in various types of campaigns.
• The complexities of persuasion within media campaigns.
• Cultural dimensions of media campaigns in different countries and social backgrounds.
• Explain the major components of media campaigns, the primary outcome variables, and the individual difference and social psychological variable associated with message receivers.
• Analyze and critique the effectiveness of media campaigns within a business, health, or political context.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81278,2018,Media Economics and Media Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In media studies, research tends to focus on the output of media industries. In this course, we take another perspective by investigating the strategic behavior of media firms that lies behind the media products we use. How did Facebook come to dominate the social media market? And how are incumbent TV broadcasters responding to the challenges posed by Youtube and Netflix? In order to study these and other questions, we will first address the particular characteristics of media products. For instance, media products often operate in dual product markets (advertisers and users), are

experience and cultural goods,-and often have zero marginal costs. In addition, media products are subject to fast-paced technological changes, globalization and great societal (e.g. political) pressures.

In order to study how market pressures and the nature of media products are impacting strategic behavior of media firms we will discuss and apply media management literature. We will take an explicit international perspective, using case studies from many different parts of the world. In these case studies, we will study how the specific economic characteristics of the media product and societal context within it is offered, affected the strategic management decisions that were made.
Note: The minimum number of participants is 6, the maximum number is 25. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Major theoretical perspectives and key concepts in media economics.
• Current perspectives on the strategic management of media companies and the impact of external pressures (market, regulation, globalization etc.) on media firms' strategies.
• Analyze media products, media firms and media markets from an economic for-profit perspective.
• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media products.
• Formulate the implications of media economic analyses for strategic management decisions of media firms.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81263,2018,Media Entertainment Fans & Franchises,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SMR Driessen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Most of us participate with media entertainment on an everyday basis. We watch movies via Netflix or stream music via Spotify. Some move beyond mere engagement and ‘invest’ greatly in their objects of affection (e.g. movies or musicians), e.g. by maintaining social media-accounts, or writing fan fiction. We can define such audience members as fans: the most passionate, but also the most critical consumers of media entertainment products.

In this seminar we explore this high level of participation in and with different media franchises, e.g. Netflix, Marvel’s superhero universe, Harry Potter, K-pop, American Idol, or influencers. Moreover, we will focus on topics like understanding (transcultural) fandom, produsing, fan tourism, crowdfunding, and storytelling. By looking at these different international franchises and their markets, we can discuss questions like: Why and how do fans engage with media entertainment franchises? How do the role and activities of fandoms change in the expanding world of media entertainment franchises? And, what are the (fan related-marketing) strategies of these franchises?
Every week different we’ll discussed different aspects of fandoms and franchises, applied to various forms of media entertainment like music, games, and movies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on media entertainment, particular fandom and media franchises.
• The relation between media entertainment, fandoms and franchises.
• Critically assess and compare existing theories on media entertainment, fan cultures and media franchises.
• Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
• Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82922,2018,Media Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current concepts, approaches and theories of entrepreneurship for working in media organizations and mediated contexts;
• The importance of entrepreneurship around media and media organizations;
• How media organizations and practitioners manage entrepreneurship.
• Identify needs, opportunities and challenges for entrepreneurial actions in media and creative industries;
• Reflectively practice entrepreneurial actions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80876,2018,Media Impact on Reputation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. JP Cornelissen'],,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81214,2018,Media Industries and Audiences,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CJ Billedo, MA', 'dr. A Paz Alencar', 'dr. AJC van der Hoeven', 'dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves', 'dr. ML Wayne', 'dr. N Mena Montes', 'I Blum, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81241,2018,Media Industries: Trends and Strategies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['EJ de Groot', 'PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.
• This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2058 - Media Industries: Trends & Strategies course.

Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries and media innovation. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81314,2018,Media Policies and Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Governments have always had a special interest in media markets. These interests derive from societal expectations that countries have of their media sector. These expectations can have political, socio-cultural and economic dimensions. The fast-paced changes in the media industry has forced governments around the world to reassess their media policy. For instance, the scandal around Cambridge Analytica’s usage of Facebook users’ data has forced many governments to rethink their privacy regulations. Although it lobbied actively against it, the new EU legalization on privacy that went into effect on the 25th of May 2018 and gives users more control over the usage of their personal data, is now being used by Facebook to improve their privacy policies, also outside of the EU.

Needless to say that governmental policy can have a great impact on media markets. During this course, we will use models from media economic scholars and institutional economics to conceptualize the interplay between government policy and media markets. In addition, we will focus on theories and developments around policy and regulation that allows us to analyze, critically assess and contextualize media policy.

This seminar connects relevant issues within media policy to relevant theoretical concepts. For instance, in all Western countries a debate is raging on fake news, freedom of speech and the right to privacy. In Asia, we see several governments taking an active role in shaping the digital environment, such as China’s Digital Wall policy that closes off Chinese audiences from unwanted media content and services.  We will discuss these and other developments in media policy using practical and international examples. Furthermore, we will try to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have taken.
The seminar is participative in nature, which means that students are required to prepare the lecture, participate in discussions and debat and give presentations.
Note: Voor dit vak geldt er een maximum van 25 deelnemers. Bij overtekening hebben studenten M&C voorrang.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the interplay between media markets, media firms and governmental policy
• relevant theories to analyze media policy

• global differences in media policy traditions
• analyse media policy
• reflect critically on relevant theory and developments in media policy
• analyse and critically evaluate different policy options
• assess the impact of governmental policy on media markets

<body>This course introduces students with major theoretical perspectives and methodological approaches in the study of media systems and media industries. The course offers a wide-ranging survey of media systems across different regions of the world. Students will be familiarized with comparative research, addressing the economic, social, political, regulatory and cultural aspects of media systems. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81092,2018,Media Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>From Hobbiton to Graceland to 221b Baker Street, media tourism – visiting places in the wake of popular media texts and objects – is a growing industry. While connected to traditional forms of sightseeing, media tourism asks different questions about the relationship between the mass media, its audiences, and physical places. What are tourists looking for? How are these attractions marketed and managed? And what about the locals, who see their home suddenly becoming a fictional location swarming with tourists? What does the increased prominence of this kind of tourism say about the relationship between imagination and reality in an era characterized by an increasing omnipresence of the media and global mobility? These are the sort of questions asked in this course. Students will explore different aspects of media tourism, from its origins and history, its connection to other parts of the tourism industry, its relationships to audience- and fan-practices, managerial aspects, and tourist experiences in order to foster a sophisticated understanding of this multifaceted phenomenon. Starting from this, students will create their own small research project on an aspect of media tourism that interests them. Students will use research techniques and methodology from cultural studies and qualitative sociology, hence it is advised to be familiar with these before partaking the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This research workshop will introduce students to the key issues in media tourism: that is, tourism inspired by (popular) media, such as films, TV-series, music, literature and video-games. Students will be able to identify the current themes within the studies of media tourism and related fields to orient themselves within the relevant theories and methods. Students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of media tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Students will extend this knowledge through small qualitative research and hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data, developing a research design and reporting on their findings.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia allowing customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy in the tourism sector where certain intermediaries have become digital. In fact, change seems to be occurring across different industries with the advent of new media: we use mobile phones to check-in at airports through SMS barcodes; customers willingly watch ads in exchange for free television shows offered online by media companies; cancer patients verify treatment choices through online support groups; prostitutes use online platforms to significantly increase their revenue. These shifts are however not necessarily unprecedented in the business world. If we look back, older information and communication media such as print, the radio and television have played a part in the shaping of diverse business models. Additionally, it is worth considering to what extent media transforms the business culture in its varied dimensions - legal, socio-cultural, economic and political. Also, how are companies’ online business presence syncing with their brick-and-mortar entities? Thereby, this course serves to create a historical and cultural overview of the role of information and communication media in the business sector and the opportunity to critically assess claims on radical shifts in organizational work practices and spaces. This includes a reexamining of the dichotomy between virtual and real business in our current digitally-mediated environments. To do so, we look closely at the complex relations between the state, the market and the public.

To best situate such overarching understandings of the relations between business and media, this course applies theory to real world business news, trends, and events concerning social media and the internet. Emphasis will be placed on emerging markets and their usage of media to restructure their role in the global economy. Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical and global perspective on the role of media in the shaping of businesses across cultures, histories and contexts.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 50. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • State-of-the art theory and research on the (changing) nature and impact of communication media in the private sector.
• How new media compare to old media in their effects on business processes.
• The relationship between virtual and material geographies of corporate cultures.
• Different business models across cultures, nations, and sectors and their usage of media.
• The legal, socio-cultural, economic, political and technical challenges that arise with the intervention of media in business.
• Companies' public responsibilities and ethics in their usage of social media.
• Critically assess claims of new media impact on business models through a historical and comparative approach.
• Analyze existing research relating organizations, digital cultures and media forms.
• Create an argumentation on a particular private or public sector and its usage of new media

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
· Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of consumer culture
· The history and commercial and social aspects of advertising
· Integrate knowledge gained from specific topics and integrate this in a focus written report
· Apply a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and critically reflect on the advertising industry’s influence on society
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83320,2018,Media and Migration,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Paz Alencar'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to search for better economic conditions and employment, to escape from war, conflicts or hunger, to flee from political persecution and religious intolerance to name a few. In recent years, however, continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in Europe and elsewhere have led to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of the so-called transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as the multiple embeddings of migrants in their host and origin places. In this course, we will focus on the critical role played by media and communication in the different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in the social media scenarios, from political negotiation between relevant actors in the field of policy-making through the organizational side of hiring migrants to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

The purpose of this course is to provide a platform for students to develop their own approach to a better understanding of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (European and non-European) and types of migration (e.g. economic migrants, second-generation migrants, expats, refugees, asylum migrants, etc.). In eight weeks, students will work in small groups to create a series of blog posts that include topics related to media, communication and (transnational) migration processes. The students’ commitment to carry out such a joint endeavour will entail a further commitment to investigating migration and transnational contexts, using theories and empirical analyses in their argument, contacting relevant migration actors, practicing intercultural skills training for conducting research and/or working in this field, exploring the potential of stakeholders, among others. Furthermore, these sessions will help students gain conceptual, empirical and practical skills and knowledge for the development of their master thesis projects in this field. This knowledge will be further applied in the weekly workshops through in-class activities and assignments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing both theoretical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.
Upon completion of this course the students will be able to:

column2: • understand the key theories and concepts (acculturation, identities, social capital, media affordances, digital divide, media framing, etc.) and methodologies (qualitative and quantitative approaches) used in research on the relationships between media, migration and intercultural communication in a transnational context (content).
• apply their knowledge to the production of their online project and Master thesis proposal at a later stage of the MA programme (content and performance).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81227,2018,Media and Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DD Dumitrica'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicianslike public figures in generaltry to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of compromising their politics to become more mediagenic. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products and approach them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media can be influential in this respect: not just broadcast and online news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Mainstream media have traditionally enabled politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. While new technologies are used in similar ways, they also offer new possibilities for alternative organizations and citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, in turn, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions affect democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicianslike public figures in generaltry to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of compromising their politics to become more mediagenic. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products and approach them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re-politicization and/or de-politicization.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83825,2018,Media and Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. N Mena Montes'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces the students to the key concepts and issues in the field of Political Communication and ‘mediated’ politics. The media provides citizens with an idea of how the world of politics looks like and how it operates in order to influence other spheres of society. Both traditional and new social media enable politicians, governments and other political opinion leaders shape public debates about social problems, policies.

In this course we will pay attention to politicians, journalist and citizens interactions and the ways in which these interactions play a role in democracy. It also explores how media technologies and formats shape political decision making; how political forces influence media organizations; and how public opinion and media audiences interact with media and political debates. Topics covered include the role of news media in a democracy, propaganda and fake news, journalism and political-media constraints, media coverage in times of war and crisis, politics and media entertainment…

Media and Politics provides the students with the skills and knowledge necessary for critical understanding of the issues that link media, politics and public opinion. In that respect, students will develop analytical skills through class participation, in-depth readings, class discussions, assignments and relevant case studies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
•    The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in the international context.
•    The roles of journalists, politicians, and citizens in the political debates and communication processes.
•    The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behaviour, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
•    The factors and processes that shape political media content in specific way.
Students have developed the proficiency/skills to:
•    Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
•    Capacity to understand and critically interpret media-related events and practices, using the tools and concepts of media and communications studies.
•    Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.
•    Capacity to participate in a press conference.
•    Structure and present ideas and thoughts in public presentations and debates.
•    Understand the importance of the Internet and new media in the modern information age and the profound effect it has on media coverage, campaigns, and privacy.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81295,2018,Media and Power,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JM Engelbert'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We seem to enjoy more (personal) freedom and autonomy than ever before. Yet we have never been governed and monitored as much as we are now. How can we explain this? And how do media technologies, contents and practices feature in this paradox? This seminar aims to provide students with the theoretical and methodological tools to address these two questions. It approaches power and governance, and the role of media therein, through the academic lens of “governmentality” scholarship. This multidisciplinary scholarship understands (mediated) power in contemporary societies to be exercised more through individuals’ positive willingness to participate in their own governance than through the negative enforcement of law by the state. Consequently, this seminar explores the role of specific media technologies (e.g., digital media or ‘brandscapes’), contents (e.g., lifestyle TV) and practices (e.g., #MeToo, Ice Bucket Challenge) in the production and reproduction of ‘common sense’ ideas about (public) issues, freedom, responsibility, blame, opportunity, risk and safety.

Note: The maximum number of students for the seminar is 16. The seminar is only accessible for MCS students and Research Master students SCMA. In case of less than 6 participants, the course will not be offered.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
•         How governmentality scholarship, as a specific academic approach, theorizes and analyses power and rule in contemporary neoliberal societies.
•         How governmentality scholarship theorizes and analyses the role of media technologies, contents and practices in neoliberal governmentality.
•         How neoliberal governmentality works through privatization, depoliticization and (in)securitization.
•         How media technologies, contents and practices feature in these strategies of neoliberal governmentality.
•  Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered to contemporary media examples of their own finding and in their own work.
•  Independently use and illustrate academic concepts and theories from governmentality scholarship covered to evaluate popular analyses of media and power in contemporary society.
•  Use their written (course-)work to convincingly argue and defend theoretical stances and empirical claims during class discussions.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81292,2018,Media and Social-Cultural Change,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. I Awad Cherit'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio-cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change or even determine it? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles do people—activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example—play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions and explores answers offered not only in the academic literature, but also by individuals who work in the media and in the promotion of social change. In order to interpret and assess these answers we will rely on theories from communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. We will pay special attention, for example, to ideology and hegemony, to (journalistic) objectivity, mediatization, media/technological determinism, and agency. Since the relationship between the media and socio-cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course will adopt a historical and cross-national perspective. Course activities will include group presentations, active participation in the course blog, interviews with practitioners and a final essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Different ways in which media stimulate or hinder socio-cultural change.
• Current academic perspectives towards the media and social-cultural change and key theoretical concepts therein.
• How current socio-political and technological developments are affecting the media’s role in relation to social change.
• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of the perspectives covered.
• Take and defend theoretical positions.
• Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered to contemporary case studies and/in their own work.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81318,2018,Media en Ondernemerschap,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. CE Aalberts'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bjzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing en crowdfunding passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • Businessmodellen in de mediasector;
• Onderzoek naar ondernemerschap in de mediasector;
• Actuele voorbeelden van ondernemerschap in de mediasector.
• De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein;
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen;
• De maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81256,2018,Media in Latin-America,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media. It strives to provide with a panorama of what is happening across the continent and examine the role of media in politics, and its relationship to national identity and state building. The sessions will discuss on a country basis; the build-up of national media production and the flow of media, into, across and out of Latin America; as well as the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America. Theoretically, we will examine approaches that have originated in Latin America: hybridity, dependency, imperialism, globalization, as well as, the development of geo-cultural and cultural- linguistic regions. An element of this course will include watching and discussing media from the region, as well as evaluations made in and outside the region. Specialists from different areas of the region will provide lectures in order to explore more closely the link among the media formats, contents and the changing social realities in the Latin-American region.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media, includying the role it plays in politics and its relationship to national identity and state building. It will cover the build-up of national media production and the flow of media into, across and out of Latin America; the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81223,2018,Media, Children and Parents",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. P Nikken'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on children's media use and on parents and educators who raise their children to media-literate persons. The child's media-landscape will be discussed together with theories on how the media may influence children. Next the role of parents will be discussed. Parents can use various strategies to further positive media effects such as learning, or dampen negative effects such as fear reactions or aggression. Students will be stimulated to explore and think about their own experiences and ideas on the strategies that parents use with traditional media as television and cinema movies, and with modern media such as computers, game consoles, smart phones, and tablets. Furthermore, we will look at tools that exist for parents, such as rating systems (Kijkwijzer and PEGI), technical safety applications on the computer, and several information and advice sources, such as Common Sense Media. The final goal of this course is a to propose a practical tool for supporting parents in guiding their children’s media use.
Note: the course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Different academic perspectives on parents' mediation of their children’s media use.
• The contemporary children's media landscape.
• How and why parents guide their children's media consumption; parenting support tools, such as rating systems.
• Critically reflect upon different academic perspectives and theories on parental mediation.
• Independently apply these in their own writings and (desk)research.
• Present their ideas on parental mediation to an audience of fellow students.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81291,2018,Media, Culture and Globalisation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AJC van der Hoeven'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course focuses on the key role of media and media entertainment in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but

the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. satellite television, digital technology, internet) and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalization developments in the media industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as  the alleged end of the nation state, global cities, multiculturalism and cosmopolitanism.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79802,2018,Media, Governance and Politics",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. RFI Moody', 'JJ Hassoldt, MSc', 'prof.dr. EH Klijn', 'S van Rijswijk, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The goal of the course deals with

column5: Being able to explain the most important theories on mass communication and the functioning of the media, also in relation to branding
Explaining what relevant developments are in the relation between media, public administration and society
Analyzing different aspects of these developments by using concrete examples.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83162,2018,Media, Trust and Morality",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['NV Roudakova'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course discusses pressing moral issues we are confronted with in our daily lives in the age of Google, Instagram and Twitter. Can we do good through the media? How do we develop moral character, build solidarity and trust, and make the right moral choices for ourselves and for our communities when our lives are so thoroughly mediated by technology?

We will draw on tools from philosophy to help us navigate through these challenges. We will consider, for example, social media as spaces that encourage apathy and disengagement (just “lurking”), but also as enabling campaigns like #metoo and #BringBackOurGirls. We will ask whether and when these campaigns are “feel-good” driven and when they are signs of actual political engagement. We will discuss the social responsibility of big tech companies, and the effectiveness of campaigns like #DeleteFacebook and #BoycottAmazon as ways to channel citizens’ outrage. Is it OK to participate in the digital economy by contributing cheap labor through blogging, citizen journalism, driving for Uber, or hosting for AirBnB? What is the right course of action when we are confronted with the mediated pain of distant others? How do we combat “compassion fatigue”? How do we deal with “fake news”? How do we act appropriately during periods of moral panic and public shaming? Is the intriguing Slow Media movement a solution to some of these challenges?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key philosophical concepts as they apply to media practice and daily life
• Key media-related virtues, such as media hospitality and care, truth-seeking, trustworthiness, courage, and justice-seeking
• How those concepts may vary historically and culturally
• Apply fundamental concepts from ethics and moral philosophy to contemporary problems of a media-saturated world
• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different moral approaches covered in class
• Independently apply academic concepts and theories to new case studies

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Mediation topics include: 1) simple mediation with any type of independent and dependent variables (i.e., continuous, dichotomous, multicategorical), 2) mediation with multiple parallel mediators, 3) mediation with multiple serial mediators. Moderation topics include: 1) moderation models with up to 2 moderators (3-way interactions) using any type of independent and dependent variables, 2) analysis of unconditional versus conditional effects, 3) Model estimation and interpretation, 4) Visualization. I will also discuss how to analyze conditional process models (i.e., models that include both mediation and moderation). Depending on the pace of the course I will also try to cover some specialized topics such as mediation analysis in within-participants designs and mediation analysis using a binary mediator. The course will be focused on teaching you how to conduct the appropriate analysis and interpret your results. We will be using PROCESS (Hayes, 2017) for the purposes of this course. Attendants should have a recent version of SPSS (or SAS) and PROCESS installed on their computer.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course you will learn how to conduct and interpret the results of mediation, moderation, and conditional process analyses. Mediation describes the case where an independent variable X influences another variable M (mediator), which in turn influences the dependent variable Y. For example, giving time to others (X) has been shown to enhance one’s own feelings of competence (M), which in turn leads to the feeling that one has more time available (Y), (Mogilner, Chance, and Norton 2012). Moderation describes the case where the effect of the independent variable X on the dependent variable Y changes across different levels of another variable M (moderator). For instance, perceived conflict between goals (X) makes consumers feel that they have less time available (Y) and this effect is further moderated by breathing speed (M). When consumers are nudged to breathe slowly the negative effect of perceived goal conflict on feelings of time is reduced (Etkin, Evangelidis, and Aaker 2015). Conditional process models combine mediation with moderation.

This is an applied course: knowledge of algebra is not required. However, a basic understanding of OLS regression is necessary. This course is targeted to any person doing social science research that wants to learn how to test for mediation and moderation in his or her data.

column1: body { font-size: 9pt; mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this module we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. The first couple of meetings are devoted to the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent). Next, we will focus on issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Upon completion of this course students will have the ability to:

column5: identify and analyse moral problems in medical and public health ethics, notably on issues concerning medically assisted reproduction, end-of-life decisions, organ donation, enhancement technologies, public health measures, and justice in health care;
analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates;
to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate;
argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments;
evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays a very important role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.
The course addresses cognitive and biological aspects of human memory. The following topics will be discussed.
The Neural Basis of Memory and Memory Disorders

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course has the following learning objectives:

column2: • At the end of the course students have basic knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of short-term/working memory.
• At the end of the course students have basic knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of long-term memory (including semantic and implicit memory tasks).
• At the end of the course students have a basic understanding of some important (mathematical) models of human memory.
• At the end of the course students have basic knowledge of the biological basis of human memory.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79892,2018,Mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['prof.dr. KAM Henrard, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De minor ‘Mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving’ is zeer geschikt voor studenten die interesse hebben in de fundamentele rechten van de mens. In deze minor worden verschillende mensenrechten behandeld en wordt bekeken wat de rol van deze mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving is. Onderwerpen als recht op gelijke behandeling, godsdienstvrijheid, vrijheid van meningsuiting, recht op onderwijs, gelijke toegang tot tewerkstelling en publieke diensten komen tijdens deze minor aan bod, met bijzonder aandacht voor de positie van minderheden (inclusief migranten), van LGBT, en vrouwen. Daarnaast wordt in het onderwijs aandacht besteed aan (actuele) maatschappelijke vraagstukken op deze terreinen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze minor verrijkt het (dominante) juridische perspectief over mensenrechten en hun rol binnen een pluriforme samenleving, met een sociaal-wetenschappelijk perspectief. Het volgen van deze minor stelt je in staat om problemen rond de multiculturele en pluriforme samenleving te identificeren, te benoemen in termen van (bepaalde) mensenrechten en eventuele botsingen tussen mensenrechten te analyseren vanuit dit dubbele perspectief.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Module A: Academische studievaardigheden in blok 1, 2 en 3. Academische studievaardigheden beoogt studenten een goede start van hun studie te bieden. Daarnaast biedt Academische studievaardigheden begeleiding in het kader van het Bindend Studie Advies (BSA). Elke mentorgroep bestaat uit maximaal vijftien studenten, die begeleid worden door een vaste mentor (een ouderejaarsstudent). Tijdens plenaire bijeenkomsten ontvangen de studenten informatie over het studeren aan de ESE en worden effectieve studiemethoden besproken. Daarnaast heeft elke student drie individuele gesprekken met de mentor om zijn of haar studieresultaten te bespreken.

• Module B: Academische presentatievaardigheden. Deze module vindt plaats in blok 2. Studenten werken met een online applicatie om hun presentatievaardigheden te oefenen. Daarnaast moeten de studenten enkele opdrachten uitvoeren en een presentatie geven.

column5: Studenten kunnen reflecteren op hun eigen studiegedrag en hun studiegedrag aanpassen op basis van feedback.
Studenten kunnen stelling nemen ten aanzien van een economisch onderwerp en deze verdedigen in een groepsdiscussie.
