<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Generalized linear models (GLM, 2 lectures). The generalized linear model extends the ordinary linear regression model by allowing non-normal distributions for response variables, and contains several useful models as special cases. The general theory is discussed, and exemplified by logistic regression, Poisson regression and social network analysis.

• Structural equation models (SEM, 4 lectures). The structural equation model  is a multivariate statistical model which postulates linear relations and associations between latent variables (such as attitudes, intentions and behaviour) and measured variables. In this course we will work with path diagrams, graphical representations of structural equation models. Moreover, we view a structural equation model as a combination of a measurement model and a structural model. The measurement model is a confirmatory factor analysis model, and the structural model is a simultaneous equations model. After discussing the confirmatory factor analysis model and the simultaneous equations model, the structural equations model is obtained as their combination.

• Multilevel models (MLM, 4 lectures). Hierarchical data consist of lower-level units organized in higher level(s):  individuals (students, employees) organized in groups (schools, firms), say. Data is obtained from measurements at different levels: at individual level and at group level. The multilevel model (MLM) describes the relations between variables measured at different levels. Special multilevel models are hierarchical linear models, random coefficient models, growth curves, random effects models and mixed models, among others.

column1: The three parts of the course do have modelling issues in common: measured and latent variables, multi-level data, non-normal data, measurement, simultaneous equations, exogeneous and endogeneous variables, fixed and random effects, variance components. In fact, attempts have been made to construct a comprehensive model.

The models discussed in this course go beyond the linear regression model. As least squares does not suffice as an estimation method, we resort to likelihood methods for GLM, SEM as well as MLM.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The purpose of this course is two-fold:

column2: • The linear regression model discussed in Applied Econometrics is extended in several directions: in particular, non-normal data, measured and latent variables, multi-level data, fixed and random effects are considered.

• Likelihood methods are introduced. As we go beyond the linear regression model, least squares does not suffice as an estimation method anymore. In this course we learn about maximum likelihood estimation, the likelihood ratio test and variants, and model selection via information criteria.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/79711,2018,Modern Families,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Bartova', 'L van der Storm, MSc', 'prof.dr. PA Dykstra']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The interplay between families and macro-level contexts is crucial for understanding the problems which modern societies face. Families are a key link between macro-level processes (political, cultural, and economic shifts) and individual outcomes such as socioeconomic and health status in later life. In other words, many of the decisions that you might perceive as fundamentally personal and individual (the kind of job taken or whether to work at all, whether to become a parent or not, which country to live in) are shaped by the interaction between our families and broader social, cultural, and institutional conditions. Furthermore, the significant changes observed in the family arena in the past decades (e.g., decreasing fertility rates, shifts in the division of paid and unpaid labour between partners) have crucial repercussions for the challenges which societies already are and will continue to face in the future (the aging of populations, supply of skilled labour, increases in inequality, social cohesion). Understanding the precursors and consequences of family-related changes is an essential step in tackling the larger societal problems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Explain the key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and apply these to specific problems (e.g., who provides support to aging parents; when to retire; the decision to move to a new country);
• Indicate the major changes in family life in Western societies and elucidate their consequences for macro-level institutions (e.g., labour market, care services);
• Illustrate how macro-level forces (e.g., policies, cultural climate, economic circumstances) shape family relationships;
• Assess the impact of family relationships on individual life courses and outcomes (e.g., employment, health, and socioeconomic status).

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:

column2: • Read and evaluate research published in academic journals and popular / policy publications;
• Deliver oral presentations that build arguments and assess evidence in a clear and effective manner;
• Present arguments on how broad-based structures and institutional dynamics shape families and individual lives;
• Improved reading, speaking, and writing in English.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83335,2018,Modernity,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. CDC van der Veeke', 'dr. R van den Akker']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the Communist Manifesto (1848), Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels characterized modernity as the historical moment in which ‘all that is solid melts into air, all that is holy is profaned, and man is at last compelled to face with sober senses his real conditions of life, and his relations with his kind.’ In this course, we will discuss this elegant, yet slippery statement on the “essence” of modernity by looking into the philosophical, social, economic and institutional aspects of the process of modernization.

While reading and discussing texts from disciplines such as History, Political economy, Philosophy and the Philosophy of History, we will focus on four interrelated questions that all circle around the notion of ‘Timely Reflections.’ What is the historical context of some of the most canonical thinkers on modernity? What can these thinkers teach us about their historical context? Why did all of these thinkers reflect on History (with a capital ‘H’) and the relation between the past, present and future? And why are their texts still relevant today?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course students are able to

column2: • Describe and explain in which ways Modernity is rooted in the Enlightenment;
• Describe and explain the emergence of typically modern institutions, such as the state, civil society, the family, and the market;
• Describe and explain the industrial revolution and the industrialization of society;
• Describe and explain the ways in which industrialization is related to wider developments such as the emergence of capitalism and urbanization;
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions produce docile bodies by means of disciplinary techniques.
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions are mobilized and have dissolved with the emergence of totalitarian movements and regimes.
• Describe and explain in which ways Enlightenment Reason has been incorporated and criticized in the dominant tradition of modern (continental) philosophy;
• Describe and explain the ways in which canonical thinkers – i.e. Kant, Hegel, Marx, Foucault and Arendt – have reflected on their own times and the concept of History.
• have an understanding of the continuities and discontinuities in the rise of the natural sciences in the 16th to 18th Century;
• have an understanding of the rise of the social sciences and humanities in the 19th Century;
• have knowledge about the ways in which scientists and others (i.e. non-scientists) engage in engage in discussions on ‘objective knowledge’;
• have a understanding of the consequences of the democratization of science
• have a clear understanding of the relations between science, policy and practice.
• can explain how science and technology are as much the products of the societies in which they are embedded as that the give shape to those societies

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80388,2018,Molecular & Cellular Biology,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. SR Mazurek'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles of 'life', with a focus on molecular and cellular biology. Cell biology studies the structure, function, and behaviour of cells, whereas molecular biology describes the molecular basis of biological activity between various biomolecules (like DNA, RNA and proteins). The course begins with an overview of the main features of bacterial, plant and mammalian cells and goes on to introduce the key molecular players in the cells, i.e. proteins. Techniques that enable characterization, isolation, and manipulation of cells and biomolecules are central in molecular and cellular biology, and these techniques therefore also play a principal role in this course. Specifically, we will take a close look at microscopy, cell culture, DNA cloning and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technology. We will then move on to study the regulation of gene expression and the eukaryotic cell cycle. We will see how cells are organized in tissues and how intra- and intercellular signalling pathways are involved in controlling cell division, differentiation, and maintenance of the stem cell state. The final part of the course will focus on how DNA can be damaged and repaired, and which molecular events are involved in the generation of cancer.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After taking this course the student will be able to:
• Understand the principles of biological systematics, taxonomy and the classification of ‘life’;
• Identify and describe the structure of bacterial, animal and plant cells (similarities and differences);
• Recognize the vital compartments and organelles of eukaryotic cells and describe their particular function;
• Explain intracellular sorting and transport of molecules (in animal cells) and how this is related to the cytoskeleton and cell movement;
• Recognize excitable animal cells, understanding membrane and action potentials and the cellular interactions within neural pathways;
• Describe the cell cycle: DNA replication, cell growth and division (mitosis and meiosis);
• Explain molecular genetics and epigenetics: the organisation of genomes (emphasis on the human genome); genes and chromosomes; dominant and recessive alleles; inheritance;
• Characterize signal transduction pathways: from an extracellular ligand to transcription activation;
• Understand the regulation of gene expression: the function of promoters, enhancers, transcription factors and small RNAs;
• Describe the various steps involved molecular carcinogenesis;
• Explain the concepts of DNA modification and cloning, including transgenesis;
• Understand the principles of DNA and (whole-) genome sequencing.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80389,2018,Molecular & Cellular Biology Lab,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. AM Aalto'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this practical course, you will become acquainted with microscopy as well as a variety of microbiological and molecular biological techniques. The preparation, planning and execution of the experiments, and the use of specific laboratory materials and equipment, will form a solid introduction to many aspects related to lab work. In microscopy, you will focus on the use and applications of the light microscope. Regarding the microbiological experiments, the focus will be on basic techniques such as the production of culture medium and the plating, staining and quantification of bacteria. The molecular biological techniques that you will perform include the isolation of plasmid DNA and determination of the purity of the DNA by spectrophotometry. In addition, the length of the isolated plasmid DNA will be determined by both restriction enzyme digestion analysis and PCR.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of the course the students will:
• Be able to accurately work with a variable micropipette
• Work according to the general safety rules and the current safe microbial techniques (SMT; in Dutch 'veilige microbiologische technieken' or VMT) rules
• Be able to prepare culture media
• Estimate the quantity of micro-organisms (colony-forming unit)
• Be able to make a DNA UV spectrum and interpret it
• Be able to isolate plasmid DNA from a bacterial culture
• Be able to execute electrophoresis using agarose
• Be able to determine the size of an unknown DNA fragment by means of the electrophoresis data
• Be able to execute a simple PCR experiment and interpret the results
• Be able to operate the light microscope quickly and correctly
• Be able to make various microscopic preparations
• Be able to keep the labjournal in an organised fashion and write lab reports
• Be able to do the calculations involved in these experiments

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In this course we concern ourselves with the ways in which health and healthcare have come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policy-making and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The traditional image of policy as a linear process from policy conception, via implementation to evaluation has thereby been left behind. In this course, we discuss different models that have been advanced to come to grips with this increased uncertainty and complexity in policymaking, both in terms of understanding and analysing policy processes and in the process of governing health and healthcare itself.

Apart from theoretical input, the course will use two cases to explore several key governance processes: integrated care and prevention, and eHealth (but these may be subject to change). We discuss the position of key actors (e.g. professionals, patients, regulators), underlying governance mechanisms (e.g. the New Public Management, self-management and ‘positive health’) and the effects of specific policy instruments. We use a comparative perspective looking at experiences in different countries and across different fields of healthcare (e.g. hospital care, long-term care and mental healthcare). During the course the students work on an essay on a current issue in healthcare governance. Apart from the essay grading will be based on an open-questions exam.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you will be able to:

column2: • Understanding the functional differences between genes, pesudogenes and non-coding RNA's
• Ecplain how genes are organized on chromosomes and how they are expressed, i.e. transcribed and translated

• Describe the molecular techniques, such as comparative genomic hybridization (CHG), fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR (qPCR), gene expression profiling (array technology), DNA/RNA sequencing using next generation sequencing technology (NGS), which enabl chromosome and genome analysis that are commonly being used for gene mapping and identification, clinical and prenatal diagnosis and cancer cytogenetics
• Understand the relationship between the genome and proteome, and how proteogenomics can provide valuable additional information on the composition of the genome

• Understand the typical Mendelia pattern of inheritance, or the pattern of transmission of single-gene disorders. You will be able to describe the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which mutations in genes result in recessice, dominant, X-linked and mitochondrial inheritance patterns
• Understand the genetics of common diseases with compex, non-Mendelian, inheritancem and how this relates to disease-predisposing alleles
• Explain the difference between genetic and epigenetic inheritance and the difference between and the molecular mechanisms of X-inactivation and the histone code
• Understand how determination of the recurrence risk is an important aspect of genetic counseling
• Explain the difference and underlying mechanisms of genome, chromosome and gene mutations, and be able to interpret the mutation nomenclature
• Understand how genetic polymorphisms - or single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) determine genetic diversity
• Understand the Hardy-Weinberg law in population genetics and how it's used in genetic counseling
• Understand the principles of linkage and genome-wide association studies (GWAS)
• Explain how susceptibility traits can have high or low risk allele frequency and what the impact of risk allele frequency is on clinical phenotype
• Understand what gene knock-out is and how molecual techniques, such as the Cre-lox and Crispr/Cas systems, enable gene modification in transgenic animals and plants
• Explain how and what type of viruses are being used for enabling gene therapy, and which diseases can be targeted
• Recognize and understand the ethical issues that are connected to prenatal and diagnostic screening, genetically modified organisms (GMO's), and gene therapy

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81821,2018,Moral Philosophy,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['dr. KME Bauer', 'drs. R Knipscheer, MA', 'HHJ van Straalen, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

What is right and wrong, virtue or vice? What ought we to do? What is the (Highest) Good? The course considers normative ethics and discusses the four major moral theories that attempt to formulate basic principles of morality: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism. We will also turn to meta-ethics and moral psychology in order to discuss more foundational issues: What are the background assumptions of the theories? Where do they show their limits? And what about their applicability to concrete moral problems in different fields of moral agency? We will discuss so called “moral dilemma cases”. In such cases, agents seem to be condemned to moral failure, they have a choice between plague and cholera. In which way and to what extent can each of the four theories help to evaluate and / or (re-)solve such dilemmatic situations?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Based on slides and close-reading the students of the introductory course into Moral Philosophy will be enabled to understand four major moral theories: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism.
- They will learn to analyse and compare the four theories by reference to a meta-ethical perspective.
- Finally, they will be enabled to critically discuss about the scope and limits of moral theories with regard to their applicability to so called “moral dilemma cases”.
-The students will practice debating, making clear statements and giving good reasons for their arguments.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78211,2018,Motivatie, zelfregulatie & prestaties",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,[],,"Inhoud

Why do some people perform better than others on work or study related tasks? Why does one person manage to faithfully adhere to an exercise regimen or a healthy diet while others succumb to the temptation of fast-food? Why is it sometimes difficult to put forth the effort to take on a task? Why do you sometimes postpone tasks even though you know you will regret this later? Why are some good intentions doomed to fail from the start? What is the purpose of planning ahead and setting goals? How can people be properly motivated to reach their potential and reach their objectives? These are just some of the central questions within the domain of motivation, self-regulation, and performance that will be addressed in this course. In addition to a short overview of the major theoretical frameworks, you will read empirical research on these topics. Emphasis is put on critical reading of the literature. The theoretical frameworks or topics that will be addressed are emotion regulation, control theory, social cognitive theory, achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, procrastination, and the possible limitation of willpower.
At the end of the course:

column2: • Students are able to differentiate between and compare the different theoretical frameworks on motivation and self-regulation (e.g., achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, ego-depletion).
• Students are able to apply these theories on situations in daily life.
• Students can give examples of self-regulatory mechanisms and are able to describe these mechanisms.
• Students can describe the relationship between motivation, self-regulation, and behavioral outcomes (e.g., performance, learning outcomes, health).
• Students can give examples and explain situations of self-regulatory failure (e.g., procrastination).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84089,2018,Motivation, Coordination, and Cognition in Enterprises",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. GWJ Hendrikse'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Enterprises are quite different from markets. First, unlike transactions involving consumer goods and services, exchanges inside enterprises cannot be disembodied from the individuals supplying them. Second, individuals in enterprises supply not only their time but also their effort, their cooperation, and a subset of their liberties to management. Third, long-term relationships are apt to develop between the parties in an enterprise. Fourth, the worker embodies specific skills or attributes that make him or her a more valuable employee to the current employer than to another company. For these reasons, enterprises tend to have characteristics that set them apart from the markets for commodities and for physical and financial assets.

These features raise issues regarding the determinants of well-functioning enterprises, such as many aspects of ‘Who decides?’ (the allocation of authority, formal versus real authority, access; relational contracts; ratification and monitoring in decision control, and initiation and implementation in decision management; task design; conflict resolution; enforcement mechanisms; talent allocation across hierarchical positions; incompatible languages and communication failures; rigid cultures, …) and ‘Benefits and Costs’ (short-termism, hard versus soft information, and vested interests in payment schemes; hiring decisions; …).

This course illuminates the nature of these issues, and their solutions. They are characterized as incentive problems (agents do not want to act in the organization’s interests), alignment challenges (agents not coordinating across departments), or bounded rationality problems (agents do not have the necessary information to do so). Successful enterprises develop and implement policies to create value, or organizations fail due to not adequately motivating and coordinating individuals toward joint goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this elective is to make you familiar with the topics at the frontier of the field of Management, especially Organizational Change and Human Resource Management. The aim is to achieve three goals:

column2: • Provide insight in motivation, coordination, and cognition problems in enterprises;
• Improve your multi-person interaction thinking;
• Enable you to develop better enterprise strategies and policies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83646,2018,Multinational financial management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. CHO Schmitt'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Multinational firms and new, rapidly-growing large enterprises access new markets across borders more than ever before. As a consequence, developing the expertise to evaluate, finance and control these opportunities requires a deep understanding of global capital markets, exchange rates, tax rules, and legal, cultural and institutional complexities. In addition, market conditions and developments in various parts of the world affect firms’ decisions across the world. This course deals with the finance aspects of multinational businesses. The course provides an analytic framework for understanding how financial management of multinational companies deals with these issues in order to create and sustain value across borders.

In this course, we first discuss the exchange rate market and the prevailing exchange rate systems. Understanding exchange rate systems and markets forms the basis for understanding currency risk, which results from international trade. In order to mitigate these risks requires the measurement and management of currency price fluctuations, i.e. corporate hedging policies. The second topic is the variety and use of derivatives to hedge various forms of risk, including exchange rate, commodity, and interest rate risk. The third topic is international financing: the possibility to raise capital (equity and debt) in international markets requires a good understanding of the opportunities and instruments that companies can use. Here we discuss the different opportunities available to managers.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: • Understand the main sources of risk faced by multinational companies.
• Measure the risk and exposure to risk of a multinational company.
• Evaluate the opportunities offered by the international bond and equity markets for large multinationals.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83163,2018,Narrative Identities in Literature and Philosophy,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. KME Bauer'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
How do you answer the question Who are you? You can just tell your name. But you can also tell a story.

Philosophical theories of narrative identity presuppose, that narrative structures are essential for the formation and / or self-understanding of personal identity, which is not reducible to a mere numerical identity.

In this course we will discuss different philosophical theories of narrative identity and confront them with different ways of unfolding narrative identities in literature. Literary narratives about fictional or real persons and their life-stories can be fragmented, multi–perspective, and very creative in their handling of fact and fiction. Literature allows us to “try on stories like clothes”. What does this tell us about philosophical theories of narrative identity and their normative implications?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- You will learn to distinguish between different philosophical theories of narrative identity and critically compare them to other theories of personal identity.
– You will be able to critically discuss the normative implications and consequences of different theories of narrative identity as well as of different ways of telling life-stories.
- You will acquire the necessary skills to enter into a fruitful dialogue between philosophy, literary theory and literature.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80421,2018,Narratives of Law & Justice,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['A Sarris, LLM', 'dr. T Ertuna Lagrand, LL.M', 'MK Dawydzik', 'mr.dr. C Bouteligier', 'mr.dr. C Elion - Valter', 'VFKB Scholtes, BSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course offers a law-and-humanities approach to core topics of law and justice, with a special emphasis on their interrelation.

column2: • The relationship between positive law and justice (both in the abstract and in concrete cases);
• The relationship between the nation-state and its citizens, both from a point of view of criminal law and administrative law;
• Contract, obligation and fairness from a civil law perspective;
• Law and the ethics of inclusion and exclusion.

column1: We will discuss these topics by means of a reading of some literary classics and relevant legal and philosophical texts. What happens to you if you are suddenly arrested without knowing why? Can you make a contract to give up a body part if you don’t deliver your part of the deal? How do you defend someone who is already condemned by the community? By reading Kafka and Shakespeare and watching To Kill a Mockingbird we get a sense of the different ways in which law may relate to justice. By confronting literature with legal texts the special character of law becomes clear. In doing so we will not only read books, but also pay attention to the films based on these stories in order to address questions of form and function of narrative in the literary and the legal text and on the screen. For example, in what way can and/or does the narrative influence our interpretation of a text or a film? This is an especially pertinent question for law since the act of interpretation is the core of doing law.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Are able to assess (at an elementary level) the scholarly debates in the field(s) of Law and Literature/Law and the Humanities.
• Are able to assess the importance of the topics discussed for the (academic) study and (professional) practice of law.
• Have gained insight into the relevance of knowledge of narrative and interpretation for law and legal practice.
• Have gained a basic to develop their ability to reflect on their knowledge in writing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81502,2018,Nationaal en internationaal procederen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['DM Kneefel', 'dr. EA Ontanu', 'MH van Putten - Lucas', 'mr. GF Strietman', 'mr. JH van Dam - Lely', 'prof.mr. AIM van Mierlo', 'prof.mr.dr. XE Kramer']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Geschillen kunnen een puur nationaal karakter hebben maar in toenemende mate zien wij geschillen met een internationale dimensie, waarin vragen van internationaal privaatrecht spelen: welk (materieel) recht is toepasselijk op de zaak, welke rechter is internationaal bevoegd en hoe het zit met de grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van een eventuele uitspraak? Als de procedure zich afspeelt voor de Nederlandse rechter, is het Nederlandse burgerlijk procesrecht van toepassing, maar dat betekent niet dat zich geen ‘grensoverschrijdende’ vragen kunnen voordoen, zoals vragen rondom internationale betekening, bewijs dat uit het buitenland moet worden verkregen en toepasselijkheid van ‘buitenlands’ materieel recht. Ook in ander opzicht doen internationalisering en globalisering zich gelden in het procesrecht. Voor de ontwikkeling van het procesrecht wordt steeds meer gekeken naar de wijze waarop het procesrecht elders is ingericht en in de EU zijn de eerste stappen gezet naar harmonisering van procedures.

Na een introductie in de leerstukken, begrippen en rechtsregels van het internationaal privaatrecht, zullen wij ter aanvulling op en verdieping van het bachelorvak burgerlijk procesrecht een aantal actuele procesrechtelijke thema’s behandelen vanuit nationaal en internationaal perspectief. Zo zullen wij aan de hand van incassozaken de nationale ontwikkelingen rond digitalisering en vereenvoudiging van procedures bestuderen alsook de vragen die spelen in internationale zaken om grensoverschrijdende incasso te vergemakkelijken (harmonisering van procedures, betekening, tenuitvoerlegging etc.). De actuele discussie in Nederland over de verhouding tussen rechter en partijen komt aan de orde, en biedt een aanknopingspunt om ons te verdiepen in het fenomeen forumshopping dat vooral in internationale zaken een rol speelt. In het licht van de rol van de rechter en de partijen besteden we ook aandacht aan de ethische dilemma’s waarvoor rechter en partijen kunnen komen te staan (voorafgaand en tijdens de procedure). Een ander voorbeeld van een thema dat in dit vak aan de orde zal komen is het bewijsrecht. De bewijslastverdeling zal vooral vanuit Nederlands perspectief worden bestudeerd; de bewijsgaring biedt een mooi aanknopingspunt om over de grenzen te kijken. We denken dan enerzijds aan de invloeden uit Europa en andere rechtsstelsels op ons nationale procesrecht (bewijsbeslag, discovery), en anderzijds aan de perikelen van grensoverschrijdende bewijsvergaring. Deze en andere actuele aspecten van het nationaal en internationaal procederen zullen na de tussentoets in de seminars van dit vak centraal staan.
Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij de voor de colleges voorgeschreven stof voorbereiden, dat zij de opdrachten serieus maken en dat zij actief participeren aan de colleges en de seminars.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student kan de voor procedures in eerste aanleg en in hoger beroep geldende regels in complexe zaken noemen, beschrijven en toepassen en vragen oplossen die voortvloeien uit het grensoverschrijdende karakter van een procedure voor de Nederlandse rechter, inclusief het bewijsrecht en het beslagrecht.

• De student kan in een vermogensrechtelijk geschil met grensoverschrijdende aspecten de relevante regels van internationaal privaatrecht bepalen en toepassen, in het bijzonder die betreffende de internationale bevoegdheid van de rechter, het op de rechtsverhouding toepasselijke materiële recht en de regels voor erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging.

• De student kan de EU verordeningen op het gebied van het civiele procesrecht, in het bijzonder die betreffende eenvormige Europese procedures, toepassen en de ontwikkelingen rond de totstandkoming en aanpassing van EU-instrumenten beoordelen.

• De student kan de ontwikkelingen in het nationale civiele procesrecht, bijvoorbeeld die aangaande de vereenvoudiging en de digitalisering van de procedure, het grievenstelsel, de (regie)rol van de rechter en partijen, het bewijsrecht en het beslagrecht analyseren, becommentariëren en daarop reflecteren.
• De student kan in ethische dilemma’s waarmee de hoofdrolspelers in een procedure kunnen worden geconfronteerd, een beargumenteerd standpunt innemen en verdedigen.

• De student kan een civiel procesrechtelijk leerstuk plaatsen in een breder rechtsvergelijkend en Europees perspectief en daarop reflecteren, bijvoorbeeld beslag, bewijs, het efficiënt voeren van procedures.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81498,2018,Nationaal studentenparlement,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. NS Efthymiou'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het Studentenparlement is een landelijke debatwedstrijd die elke 2 jaar wordt georganiseerd door de docenten van alle rechtenfaculteiten in Nederland, onder auspiciën van de Staatsrechtkring. De bedoeling is dat elke faculteit een fractie van 3 tot 8 studenten afvaardigt die een standpunt formuleert over een - door een werkgroep van docenten opgesteld - fictief wetsvoorstel. Net als bij de wetgevingsprocedure voor de Tweede Kamer is er eerst een schriftelijke fase (in de periode van oktober - februari) en vervolgens vindt in mei een mondeling debat tussen alle fracties plaats in de vergaderzaal van de Tweede Kamer.

Een onafhankelijke jury - doorgaans bestaande uit een hoogleraar staatsrecht, een of meerdere politici en een parlementair journalist - beoordeelt vervolgens de prestaties van de verschillende fracties. Winnaar is die fractie die zowel in zijn bijdrage aan het Verslag, als in het mondelinge debat de beste prestatie heeft geleverd, dat wil zeggen met het oog op het politieke karakter van het evenement, zo goed mogelijk heeft gedebatteerd.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Training van mondelinge en schriftelijke uitdrukkingsvaardigheden in het algemeen, en met betrekking tot staatsrechtelijke onderwerpen in het bijzonder;
• In teamverband verwerven van dieper inzicht in een staatsrechtelijk onderwerp.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87294,2018,Necessary Condition Analysis: Theory and Practice,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. J Dul'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A necessary condition is a critical determinant of an outcome: if the condition is not in place the outcome will not occur. A student will not be admitted to a PhD program when the GMAT score is too low, creativity will not exist without intelligence, and organizational change will not occur without management commitment. Such single conditions can be a bottleneck for the outcome. If the necessary condition is not in place there is guaranteed failure, and this cannot be compensated by other determinants. But when the condition is in place there is no guaranteed success. The condition is necessary but not sufficient. To prevent failure, each single necessary condition must be in place. Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA) provides the logic and a methodological tool for identifying necessary conditions in different datasets.

Necessary (but not sufficient) conditions are widespread in real life and therefore relevant to various research areas, such as management, business research, sociology, and psychology. But until recently no technique was available to identify necessary conditions in datasets. Traditional (regression based) data analysis techniques fail to do so, even though they are frequently applied for exactly that matter. Necessary Condition Analysis (NCA) is a new technique that can do the job (Dul 2016).

NCA is applicable to any discipline, and can provide strong results even when other analyses such as regression analysis show no or weak effects. By adding a different logic and data analysis approach, NCA adds both rigor and relevance to theory, data analysis, and publications. NCA is a straightforward and user-friendly method that requires no advanced statistical or methodological knowledge beforehand. It can be used in both quantitative research as well as in qualitative research.

NCA is a rapidly emerging empirical research method that is being used in a variety in fields such as (industrial) psychology, international business, operations management, information sciences, finance, strategy, entrepreneurship, organizational behavior, and human resource management. For example, Karwowski et al. (2016) found that intelligence is necessary for creativity. Van der Valk et al. (2016) identified trust and contracts are necessary for successful collaboration between companies for innovation. Arenius, Engel, and Klyver (2017) tested whether particular gestation activities for establishing a new firm are necessary for profit two years after the firm’s start. Furthermore, de Vries et al. (2017) found that safety consciousness is necessary for driving performance, and Knol et al. (2018) identified several necessary conditions for successful implementation of lean production.  NCA has also been applied outside the social sciences, for example in medicine (Luther et al. 2017).

In general NCA is particularly useful when several factors contribute to an outcome (multi-causality), and it is not known which factors are essential for that outcome. Research questions may deal with characteristics, efforts and steps of people, teams, and organizations that are crucial for successful outcomes (e.g., high performance).
What are the main advantages of applying NCA:

column2: • It provides new substantive insights in social science phenomena (expressed as necessity rather than average trend); using NCA provides an alternative perspective, may enhance existing research, or falsify theories;
• It has great practical meaning because identified necessary condition must always be put and kept in place
• Journal editors and reviewers appreciate that authors use a new solid methodology that provides new insights and contributes to academic rigor and practical relevance.
• “From my perspective, it is the most interesting paper I have handled at this journal, insofar as it really represents a new way to think about data analyses""
• “I just added the paper to the required reading list for my doctoral-level seminar on research methods”
• “I believe the paper holds the potential to be widely cited and to change how organizational researchers approach testing for cause and effect relationships”

column1: What participants of this course said about NCA?

column2: • “Simple technique that requires no ‘preparation’, data transformation/manipulation/ correction. A perfect plug-and-play method that can give output in under 10 minutes”
• “It’s a new way of thinking and therefore it may lead to many interesting insights, just reanalyzing old dataset”
• “Analysis provides insights that cannot be obtained with another method”
• “Insights are very relevant for practice”
• “I do believe that is has great exploratory value that is congruent with recent emphasis on big data”

column1: The course is primarily open to PhD candidates and junior faculty, but also other researchers (including master students and senior faculty) who are interested in this novel approach are welcome. It is expected that each participant has at least some experience with traditional regression analysis to understand the differences between NCA and regression, and to appreciate how NCA complements regression. Also researchers with a background in Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA) can benefit from the course to appreciate how NCA complements QCA. No special methodological or substantive knowledge is required for this course. Examples will be drawn from many different (business) fields. Each participant is expected to bring a laptop computer with a Windows (Microsoft) or IOS (Apple) operating system. The exercises with the NCA software (in R) can be done without prior programming knowledge or experience.
What is the content of the course?
The course consists of three parts:
1. Individual preparations to be done before the course (approximately 16 hours)

column2: • Participant reads literature about necessary conditions (reader)
• Participant installs the NCA software on own laptop (detailed instructions will be provided)
• NCA as logic and data analysis approach: How it works?
• Format: lecture with class discussions
• Applying NCA to own dataset
• Format: Participants works on own laptop with assistance by lecturer, and class discussions
• Content: ceiling line, effect size, accuracy, bottleneck table, interpretation of results, handling of problematic or unusual cases, how to publish findings

column2: • To gain understanding of the logic of necessary conditions, and why these are important for social science and practice;
• To be able to identify necessary conditions in (own) data sets;

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81801,2018,Negentiende eeuw I: Van Kant tot neokantianisme,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['J van der Klaauw, MA', 'prof.dr. HA Krop']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Aan het einde van de 18e eeuw ontwikkelt zich in Duitsland stormachtig het Duits idealisme op basis van de problematiek die Kants kritische filosofie deed ontstaan en die hij  in zijn derde kritiek probeerde te entameren. De basis van dit denken is Kant, met name diens teleologie, dat als model dient voor een geschiedfilosofie, die de geschiedenis leest als een proces van menselijke bevrijding en emancipatie. Hegel meende dat na de Franse Revolutie en Kants kriticisme dit proces zowel in politiek als intellectueel opzicht voltooid is met de opbouw van de moderne (rechts)staat en het ontstaan van een christendom dat tot zijn redelijke kern zou zijn herleid. Rond 1830 begint Hegels roem te verbleken.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Overzicht van de ontwikkeling van de negentiende-eeuwse wijsbegeerte te beginnen bij Kant. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen politieke en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene  en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan jet het interpreteren van filosofische teksten uit de 19e eeuw.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81800,2018,Negentiende eeuw II: Van Kant tot neokantianisme,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De snelle ontwikkeling en verbreding van de natuurwetenschappen in de achttiende en begin negentiende eeuw krijgen filosofisch een vervolg in de ontwikkeling van een empiristische kenleer en een positivistisch wereldbeeld. Ook vindt tegen deze achtergrond een empirische en ‘wetenschappelijke’ geïnspireerde benadering plaats van maatschappelijke vraagstukken en geven de door de wetenschappelijk bemiddelde  visies op kennis, natuur en menselijke samenleving aanleiding tot een steeds pregnanter idee van historische ontwikkeling.

In deze cursus zal het positivische gedachtegoed worden toegelicht aan de hand van denkers als Auguste Comte en Ernst Mach en de verdere ontwikkeling van de positivistische methodiek worden uitgelegd aan de hand van het empirisme van John Stuart Mill. Ook zullen sociale ideeën van zowel Comte als Mill worden behandeld. Zowel de historiserende als de methodologische en kentheoretische aspecten van het negentiende eeuwse denken komen terug in de behandeling van het werk van Charles Darwin en de reflectie op de filosofische gevolgen daarvan. Vanuit de Duitstalige traditie zal met name aandacht worden besteed aan Arthur Schopenhauer en Friedrich Nietzsche, die beiden een unieke positie veroverden in het filosofische landschap van de Negentiende Eeuw.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten. Studenten die hier niet aan voldoen krijgen meer vragen te beantwoorden tijdens het tentamen.

Aan het einde van de cursus zijn studenten in staat de belangrijkste thema’s uit de geschiedenis van de wijsbegeerte van de negentiende eeuw toe te lichten aan de hand van filosofische ontwikkelingen in Frankrijk, Engeland en Duitsland volgend op de periode van het Hegelianisme. De studenten krijgen een elementair inzicht in de wijze waarop de filosofische posities zich tot elkaar verhielden en hoe de historische ontwikkeling van filosofische vraagstellingen gedurende het tijdvak verliep. Waar dat van nut is voor een beter begrip van de thema’s worden filosofische ideeën in de bredere context geplaatst van culturele, politieke en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80160,2018,Network Data Analytics,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. R Crisostomo Pereira Belo'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Social Networks shape many aspects of how people and organizations interact, take decisions, and ultimately perform. With the advent of Social Media (e.g., Facebook and Twitter) and with the increasing digitization of all forms of communication and business processes, Social Network Analysis

has become a valued asset to better understand how different agents interact and how to best take advantage of the network structure to increase overall system performance. This course will cover the fundamentals of network science, the methods, theories, and the procedures for data collection
and analysis in very large social networks. Covered topics include clustering, information diffusion, organizational design, viral marketing, social media and others.

This course provides the basics of social network analytics, including fundamental network- and node-level metrics, as well as more advanced analysis methods, with attention to the application areas where these can and have been used. Students will engage in in-class projects in which

they collect and analyze network data using the tools and methods covered in class. Students will apply these methods to specific networks, such as social media networks (e.g., Twitter), co-worker networks, organization networks, and product networks.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course will teach you the fundamental skills for decision making based on social network data.
• How to use R for analysis of network data;
• Techniques and tools for social network analysis and visualization;
• Which types of network structures foster and hinder performance in specific contexts;
• How to use social network data to inform decision making.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80099,2018,Network Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. EH Klijn', 'prof.dr. JFM Koppenjan']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In our current network society governments increasingly face so called ‘wicked problems’. These are problems like the uncontrolled influx if refugees and its societal implications, attempts at inner city regeneration, conflicts over the construction or operation  of public infrastructures like roads, airports, windmill parks, health and social problems like obesities, drug use, unsafety and criminality, lack of coordination in care of elderly people or youth care. These problems are characterized by:

column2: • The involvement of many different actors
• The strong (resource) interdependencies between governments and these other involved actors
• The lack of consensus about the nature of the problem and the desired solutions
• The complexity of the issue and the lack of adequate and accepted information and expertise

column1: These problems are addressed in networks of interdependent actors. The autonomous position of the actors and their (diverging) individual strategies makes decision- and interaction processes in networks complex. In the course Network Governance we explore these complex governance processes in depth by looking at theoretical concepts of network governance and practicing network analysis on a concrete case.

Students will be introduced to theoretical concepts of governance networks and network governance in order to be able to understand and analyze the interdependence between government and society. To that end, concepts such as networks, dependencies, perceptions and different aspects of the complexity of network processes will be dealt with.

Students will also learn to interpret, understand and analyze networks and the governance processes that take place Within these networks. Finally, students will practice developing management strategies in order to influence networks and network processes. The interaction between theory and practice is the main focus of the course. In the working group sessions, students will practice with the concepts dealt with in the lectures and use the concepts to which they have been introduced to make a case analysis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • reproduce and explain the core concepts of the network governance approach
• explain the difference between the network governance approach and more traditional approaches to policy making and – implementation

• reconstruct in a given case the perceptions of actors, their strategies and the resulting decision-making process by identifying in what (possibly interdependent) arenas, specific decisions were made and what consequences of decisions can be identified
• identify and develop network management strategies that promote collective action in situations characterized by interdependence

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80151,2018,Neuroaccounting and Finance,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AM Murillo Oosterwijk', 'dr. A Sluga', 'prof.dr. FGH Hartmann']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces you to the interdisciplinary and novel field of neuroscience as it can be applied to study and understand finance and accounting. We define the field of neuroaccounting and finance as the field of theoretical and empirical enquiry that applies social cognitive neuroscience to problems of accounting, financial management, and financial markets. The course covers basic brain physiology and brain functions, but focuses mainly on studying brain and brain related processes that are involved in (financial) decision making and management of humans in organizations.

The topics that are addressed in this course include choice and decision making, information and communication, and cognitive control. The course pays special attention to some of the challenges faced by financial managers and accountants in the organization. The course also presents fundamental neuroscience empirical techniques, specifically EEG and fMRI and will include a lab visit to see these techniques in reality.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Understand the basic anatomy and physiology of the brain;
• Understand how brain processes are related to various aspects of financial decision making;
• Understand and explain the intuition behind the neuroimaging methods of fMRI and EEG;
• Explain what techniques are used to study brain processes in neuroscience at a basic level;
• Explain findings from extant neuroscience research papers;
• Draw inferences from neuroscience data in order to answer descriptive and predictive questions relevant to financial managers;
• Explain and justify managerial recommendations from neuroscience studies to non-technical audiences through written reports and presentations;
• Understand the main opportunities and challenges of modern neuroscientific methods for financial management purposes.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80195,2018,Neuromarketing,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MAS Boksem', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces the interdisciplinary field of neuromarketing. This new and exciting area in marketing aims to understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying customer responses to marketing actions, and to better predict customer behavior using brain markers.

Neuromarketing is proposed to reveal information about customer preferences and reactions to marketing actions that other techniques cannot provide (Ariely and Berns, 2010). This is based on the assumption that customers are not always able or willing to express their true preferences in questionnaires. Furthermore, measures of brain activation could assist in the early stages of the product development process thus reducing the likelihood of failures.

In recent years, the application of neuroimaging and psychophysical techniques in marketing has surged both in academia and in marketing practice. Modern brain imaging techniques of electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are commonly applied, for example, to track the emotional response to brands and TV commercials, to assess which scenes of a commercial attract attention and are memorable, to evaluate the beauty of a package or how customers trade-off price and quality. Psychophysical techniques such as eye-tracking, galvanic skin response and heart rate measurement add additional insights into the customers’ heart and mind.

Currently, most marketers are not trained in these techniques and thus have difficulty in properly evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of these methods. Clients of neuromarketing companies may get easily impressed by colourful pictures of activations in the brain which may not be truly insightful or predictive. In this course we provide the student with an up to date insight into the current body of knowledge in consumer neuroscience and neuromarketing. Accordingly, this course will provide many hands-on opportunities to develop neuromarketing skills. In assignments, the main neuroimaging techniques of fMRI and EEG will be introduced. You will collect data and learn the basics of analyzing this data.
Ariely & Berns (2010), Neuromarketing: The hope and hype of neuroimaging in business, Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 11(4), 284-292

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand the basic anatomy and working of the brain
<li>
Understand the main neural processes underlying consumer decision making and consumer reactions’ to marketing actions (i.e., branding, advertising, design and packaging, pricing, assortment)
<li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind the neuroimaging methods of fMRI and EEG
<li>
Ability to collect, analyze and report basic fMRI and EEG data
<li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind psychophysical methods (in particular, eye-tracking, face reading, heart rate and galvanic skin response)
<li>
Draw inferences from neuromarketing data in order to answer descriptive and predictive questions relevant to marketing managers
<li>
Explain and justify managerial recommendations from neuromarketing studies to non-technical audiences through written reports and presentations
<li>
Understand the main opportunities and challenges of modern neuroscientific and psychophysical methods for marketing purposes

column2: <body>

column3: Een beschadiging aan de hersenen resulteert veelal in cognitieve, emotionele, en gedragsproblemen. De psycholoog die werkzaam is in de gezondheidszorg zal deze patiënten vaak tegenkomen. Denk maar aan slachtoffers van een verkeersongeval, mensen met een herseninfarct of patiënten met de ziekte van Alzheimer. Tijdens het blok zal je vertrouwd worden gemaakt met technieken om mensen met een hersenbeschadiging te diagnosticeren en met technieken die het mogelijk maken om functies van de hersenen te bestuderen. Daarnaast wordt er in het blok aandacht besteed aan biologische modellen van psychopathologie. Tegenwoordig is dit een belangrijke stroming binnen de psychiatrie, denk maar aan de diverse psychofarmacologische behandelingsmogelijkheden van psychiatrische patiënten.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: In dit blok komt het vakgebied klinische neuropsychologie aan bod. Doel van dit blok is kennis verwerven over de relatie tussen hersenbeschadiging, gedrag, cognitieve functies en emotie, zowel bij volwassen als bij kinderen. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat er kennis verworven wordt over de rol van biologische processen bij verschillende vormen van psychopathologie. Ook de rol van psychofarmaca bij het behandelen van psychopathologie zal aan bod komen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80211,2018,New Business Development,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. Z Wu', 'L Groenewoud - van Vliet, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Most students from RSM will be confronted with new business development at some stage in their careers. In this course new business development is viewed as the firm’s ambition and effort to grow, typically by means of product, service and/or business model innovations. For many firms and organizations innovation - coupled with a strong entrepreneurial drive - is critical to maintain and grow its profitability. In this course students will develop in a multidisciplinary team a business report that focuses on one particular innovative opportunity for an existing firm.

This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the process of entrepreneurial business planning that leads to the successful creation of new business for established firms. Amongst others students will engage in feasibility analysis, business modelling, financial analysis, and the development of a repeatable and scalable sales process. In previous years, students developed actionable new business reports for - and in close collaboration with - a variety of firms, including Philips, PostNL, Heijmans, TNO, Airborne, Enexis, Ubiqu, Synthesis, Surefas, and numerous other multinationals, SMEs, and start-ups.
A detailed course schedule will be announced on Canvas.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
You will know what elements make up a new business development report and you will understand how these elements interrelate.
<li>

You will understand the complexity of the new business development process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
<li>

You will understand that new business development is based on numerous assumptions, that its process is one of testing those assumptions to turn them into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.
<li>
You will have the capability to construct and refine business models for new business opportunities.
<li>
You will have the capability to identify and prioritize the critical assumptions underlying potential business models.
<li>
Using numerous tools, techniques, and theories, you will have the capability to set-up and execute effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
<li>
You will be able to write down your new business development report concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.
<li>
You will be able to present and discuss your business plan progress in class.
<li>

You will be able to develop and discuss your business plan in a multidisciplinary student team as well as in a professional context of business relationships (e.g., company coach, investors, internal stakeholders, etc.).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Towards behavioural economics 2.0? Several proposals have been made to move (behavioural) economics beyond the stage in which economics has been enriched by psychological findings and insights. In this course, several directions are identified and discussed: Brains, Evolution, Morality, Complexity, Culture and Welfare & Policy.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the end of this course, students will have developed an informed and nuanced overview of several directions in which behavioral economics can further evolve. Testimony for this will have to be provided by writing an research paper in which students show that they have a clear idea about the about both the prospects (merits and demerits) of behavioural economics moving forward into one of these directions.
