<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This seminar is focused on understanding the impact of new communication technologies on the Marketing and Advertising Industry. This industry is continuously using creativity to face the challenges of an ever-changing media landscape that urges brands and companies to reinvent the way they communicate with their customers. During this course, we will explore how brands are taking advantage of the quick innovations in the communications and creative industries to persuade customers in new and innovative ways. We will also critically reflect on the value and social, cultural and economic implications of these new forms of branded communication.

The NMMA strategies discussed in this course include: branded entertainment, gamification and playful marketing, social media advertising and social media influencers and the use of Artificial Intelligence in Marketing and Advertising.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 25. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The impact of new communication technologies on the Marketing and Advertising Industry
• The different theoretical perspectives on the study of NMMA
• The value of scientific knowledge for the critical analysis and design of NMMA strategies and campaigns
• Critically analyze the new ways brands and companies are communicating with consumers
• Critically assess the social, cultural and economic impact of NMMA
• Apply theoretical knowledge for the design of NMMA strategies and campaigns

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81222,2018,New Media Production,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. A Paz Alencar', 'dr. D Castro Marino', 'dr. IM Derda', 'dr. N Mena Montes', 'dr. SMR Driessen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Today’s media and communication professionals need to be avid storytellers. Think about how online platforms like  Buzzfeed or VICE  manage  to capture  readers’  attention  with  a mix of entertainment and information. Or how newspaper-websites try to entertain readers with creative multimedia long- reads. This course will teach you the tricks and tools to become a skilled, enthusiast storyteller in and for the digital world. Moreover, students gain hands-on experience in this course, as media    production skills are best learned by  doing.

In eight weeks, students will work in small groups to create a digital production (consisting of a   short- and long-form) that covers a topic related to the city of Rotterdam. Particularly, a topic that   fits within the scope of the Erasmus Initiatives (Dynamics of Inclusive Prosperity; Smarter Choices for Better Health; Vital Cities and Citizens). To create such an online publication, various media

professionals will introduce students to the genre. Furthermore, these sessions will help students to gain skills like different storytelling characteristics, writing and interviewing techniques, and   journalistic practices. The media practitioners and the workshop lecturers will help explore and apply techniques of a variety of digital publication genres (the short-form/ news message, the long-form/ multimedia long-read) and traditional genres (interviews, news reports, press releases). This   knowledge will be further applied in the weekly workshops with the help of in-class exercises and assignments. Moreover, through these exercises and peer-reviewing work-in-progress, students gain skills like conceptualizing story ideas, writing for online and social media, interviewing, and reviewing.

To wrap up the course, students are to demonstrate their storytelling skills by producing a short- and long-form, showcase these publications (to peers and professionals), and are able to reflect on the production process of their publications.

Due to the practical nature of this course, literature is recommended and not mandatory. We expect    a strong curiosity to learn and get hands-on experience, and a strong work ethic to let the final  product come its full right. We will focus mainly on (non-academic!) writing skills, and being handy with or willing to put your basic skills in photography, creating and editing videos or audio (which can all be done with the help of your smartphone) to use is encouraged.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Upon completion of this course the students will be able to:

column2: • Analyse creative and communication opportunities and employ the most appropriate complex of media and rhetorical strategies to create and disseminate informative, entertaining and persuasive
• Learn how to use (and break) media production rules, using the most accessible digital and online technologies  and applications.
•
• Develop critical perspectives on media production. Anticipate the ethical implications of emerging media and their power to shape public  opinion.
• Complete original, creative projects exploring and effectively using the visual and conceptual language of new media.
• Engage in productive critical discourse about their own work and the work produced in class by their peers.
•
• Gain new media literacy, i.e. to conceptualize, analyze, critically reflect on and transform creative content  available online.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83164,2018,New Media and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Castro Marino'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

New media has transformed the way creators produce entertainment as well as redefine audience’s experiences. For example, YouTube, Facebook and Twitter, among other platforms, have been used by both professional and amateur creators to not only distribute new types of entertainment products, but to also offer a multi-screen experience to their audiences.

This research workshop will, thus, explore how new media transforms the creative process of entertainment products (e.g. TV series, videogames) and audience’s experiences. The course is divided into two main sections. In the first one, students will engage in the reading and discussion of a selected group of academic texts on the topic. In the second section of the course, students will design and carry out their own research project on new media and entertainment.

As future communication experts, students need to both understand how new media impacts both the creative process of entertainment products and the audience’s experiences. Furthermore, students will have the opportunity to put into practice (and further develop) their research skills, as well as reflect on their own media consumption practices. Finally, the workshop will offer the students a multimedia, interactive and collaborative learning environment to help them achieve the learning goals</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students will gain and advance their knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • The current dynamics between new media and entertainment creators
• The interplay between new media entertainment products and their audiences
• The role of qualitative methods in the examination of the creative industry
• Critically reflect on the claims made by researchers and theorists from western and non-western academic traditions
• Effectively design and conduct an empirical qualitative research project
• Clearly communicate research findings through both oral presentations and in an academically sound research paper
• Work with (international) peers and reflect on their own development

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81265,2018,New Media and International Business,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AE Mols', 'dr. JH Pridmore']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

New media and social media have become central to everyday life, and how these can be used effectively within international business has become an important topic for business and communication research. Mobile apps, online collaboration software, and social media from Instagram to Facebook to LinkedIn, new media have changed the way international business gets done. While these changes are have transformed logistics, team work, resource management and hiring practices, this course will specifically focus on how new media have affected and shaped (and been affected and shaped by) marketing practices and workplace communication and contact within international businesses. That is, the course will evaluate marketing practices that employ new media, specifically focusing on social media developments such as with Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest, Snapchat and more. In addition, the course will look at how policies and practices of communication that occur within international businesses are tailored (or not) to deal with the use of social media, and how this affects the internal dynamics of communication within the workplace. This includes planning and project development, daily notifications, promotions, professional and personal connections and more.

During the research workshop, students will examine in depth the practices and technologies involved in either marketing or social media use in the workplace. This approach will focus on the knowledge and technologies integrated into particular practices as solutions to particularly defined problems. For instance, with workplace communications (particularly for social media) different

organizations employ different strategies or techniques. These include using social media based planning and project technologies, limiting other social media use through technological means, monitoring employee interactions, requiring communication availability at all times of the day, encouraging employees to log off, or giving employees complete freedom. Each of these is based on a particular orientation to what social media are and what they do. Within marketing practices, companies may choose to tightly control their message and brand, engage and develop brand communities, encourage ‘open branding’ or open up their products and services for public input and much more as a means to sell more products and services. In order to achieve this conceptual and methodological knowledge, students will engage in several in-class exercises and engage in empirical evaluations of either corporate communication or marketing practices in new media use by an international business. These empirical examinations will be based on an inductive qualitative research process involving interviews or content analysis.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 100. This course is only open to IBCoM students

• In order to be admitted to Research workshop 2, students should have completed Research Workshop 1: Cross-national Comparative Communication Research(CM1011), at least one of the second year methods courses Quantitative or Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication (CM2005 or CM2006) and at least one seminar in the focus area concerned.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • How marketing and business practices shape markets through various technologies and techniques
• Differentiated levels of control (and their implications) attained by international businesses in the use of new and social media (with particular attention to marketing and human resources)
• How new and/or social media choices affect the distribution and control of information and communication
• The use of empirical cases studies in studying new media practices
• Develop and execute a small research project either focusing on new media and marketing or new media and workplace contexts
• Effectively research new media practices through empirical case studies
• Evaluate practices within international businesses, focusing on the potentials and problems that come with the use of new media
• Define problematic potentials for practices and policies within international business in relation to new media
• Report their research findings in a scientifically substantiated manner
• Work with (international) peers and reflect on their own development

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81266,2018,New Media and Political Communication,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DD Dumitrica'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Back in the mid-1990s, the rapid popularization of the Internet had raised the hope of technologically-enhanced citizen engagement in political decision-making. But the vision of an electronic democracy, where new media enable citizens to monitor and participate in the life of their polis, has failed to materialize. On the one hand, our own use of the Internet is oriented towards consumption and entertainment. On the other, the current political context prompts us to ask: what type of political content is circulated? By whom and for what purposes? And, what do individuals do with it? From discussions of cyberwarfare and fake news, to stories of targeted online abuse, the Internet no longer appears to match the vision of electronic democracy.

In this course, we focus our attention on one aspect of democratic politics: dialogue and deliberation in the public sphere. The two have long been seen as central to democracy. We ask how the Internet contributes to or hinders political dialogue and deliberation in the context of everyday life. We focus on online spaces where regular citizens engage in ‘political talk’, questioning the nature of such talk and reflecting on what could contribute to its transformation into a real Habermasian public sphere.

The knowledge gained in this course and the research you will perform will prompt you to question your own role as citizens, as well as enable you to work towards the creation of democratic communication in your chosen profession. You will be responsible for developing an original empirical research on the problematic of the course. In this process, you will enhance your understanding of qualitative research (textual analysis) on mediated communication.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 75. This course is only open to IBCoM students

• In order to be admitted to Research workshop 2, students should have completed Research Workshop 1: Cross-national Comparative Communication Research(CM1011), at least one of the second year methods courses Quantitative or Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication (CM2005 or CM2006) and at least one seminar in the focus area concerned.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Contemporary dynamics in political communication.
• The use of new media for political communication purposes.
• Qualitative content analysis and its role in examining political communication.
• Design a qualitative research project.
• Collect and analyze textual data.
• Evaluate the data in a theoretically-informed manner.
• Report their findings through oral presentations and written reports.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge of political communication.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81267,2018,New Media, Culture and Entertainment",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Entertainment and cultural products shape the identities of fans all over the world. Music, TV shows, movies, videogames and anime are all different ways of contacting with different cultures and connect with strangers. In a time where nationalism and divisions are on the rise in some parts of the world, this course explores how people connect, share experiences and produce new content related to their favorite cultural products. How do fan groups and forums organize themselves online? How is online fandom experienced in different countries and by various cultures? What is the impact of new media on community building? Do fan communities help bridge tensions and reduce polarization between different groups?

In this course we will learn how to conduct research in the world of online fandom and explore the interactions and identities of fans. Furthermore, students will learn that research about communities and identities is not limited to the field of entertainment, but that similar research methods and concepts can also be applied to other communication fields like brand communities and national identities.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25.

• In order to be admitted to Research workshop 2, students should have completed Research Workshop 1: Cross-national Comparative Communication Research(CM1011), at least one of the second year methods courses Quantitative or Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • The various ways that new media affect the field of culture and entertainment
• How entertainment products contribute to build group identities and connect different individuals and cultures
• Different kinds of new media analysis
• Analyze and evaluate (research on) the role of new media in the cultural industries and their influence on shaping identities and creating communities
• Translate theoretical notions into an empirical research design
• Empirically examine interaction practices and identities (culture and entertainment-related)
• Apply relevant research methods and techniques covered in the methodological core courses (quantitative and qualitative)
• Report research findings in a scientifically grounded manner
